results.description:
It's the January edition of our popular monthly GUY GALLERY WALK! 

This is our monthly outing where we check out all the BEST ART SHOWS in the Chelsea Gallery District! We usually see between 14-16 shows each time.

Here's the FULL ITINERARY:

1st stop: MITCHELL- INNES & NASH (534 W 26th St) presents: EDDIE MARTINEZ, SALMON EYE

1st show from this Brooklyn-based painter

Martinez is known for his large-scale, energetic canvases in which densely built-up layers of oil and enamel paint are punctuated by elements of collage.  Bold and muscular brushstrokes contrast with the faint lines of a spray can and the rich texture of paint squeezed directly from the tube to the canvas.  Synthesizing classical formal compositions such as the still-life, portrait and landscape with the speed and ‘stream of consciousness’ approach of a child’s hand, Martinez arrives at a style unmistakably his own.

The works in Salmon Eye feature a unique marriage of Martinez’s gifts as a draftsman and a painter.  Many of the paintings in the exhibition originated as small, sharpie drawings on paper.  The drawings are enlarged and silkscreened onto the canvas.  Using this black silkscreen as a starting-point, Martinez then builds up shapes and layers, sometimes using the outline of the silkscreen as a formal blueprint, or sometimes disregarding the lines or covering them entirely. 

2nd stop: CHAIM & READ (547 W 25th St) presents: JONATHAN LASKER

Lasker’s newest work continues to explore the ways in which paintings are constructed and perceived. Employing three consistent components —figure, ground, and line—Lasker’s careful arrangement of abstracted elements challenges one’s usual reaction to non-representational painting, positioning the viewer in an unexpected discourse with form and space, foreground and background, objecthood and artifice. As Lasker describes, his paintings are meant to “make the viewer see him or herself in the act of viewing,” drawing attention to “how we construct a picture in our mind.” By positioning various forms and patterns— through repetition, segmentation, and layering—to visually recede or advance in pictorial space, Lasker composes illusionary “pictures” which are at once ambiguous and decisive. Recurring figural motifs repeat throughout the paintings, acting as a sort of abstract visual vocabulary. Paralleling linguistic concepts, Lasker uses these “signs” to set up various dialogues and spatial relationships which the viewer, as if following clues, is intended to decipher. Often, a thickly rendered motif is echoed by its separate, less tactile outline; the two forms reverberate together but seem to exist on different planes, much as the missing piece of a puzzle is mimicked by its empty shape. In other works, the prominent inclusion of Lasker’s signature or initials heightens the tension between illusion and reality: dimensionality is mocked by the stubborn literalness of the painting’s two-dimensional surface. 


3rd stop: DRISCOLL BABCOCK GALLERY (525 W 25th St) presents: E. AMBROSE WEBSTER, THE PRIMACY OF COLOR


exhibition of exceptional early 20th century works by America’s greatest interpreter of Fauvism. Webster’s paintings remain startlingly innovative and evocative to this day. It is said that when word of Webster’s death reached Paris, Picasso shed a tear; closer to home, Edward Hopper, one of Webster’s neighbors in Provincetown, paused to remember a painter in whom he “could find no flaw.” Later Richard Diebenkorn wrote that “Webster committed himself uncompromisingly to the Paris experience and found his own stride within it… he could achieve weight as well as brilliance.”

Webster [masked]) was among the first and most forceful modern American painters, and he created some of the most adventurous paintings of his time. In a dynamic career spanning forty years, he traveled widely in Europe, North Africa, the Azore Islands, Jamaica and Bermuda, chasing the sun-drenched color that would inform his own high-keyed palette and superb expression of light. From the heat of his tropical canvases to the crispness of his New England snowscapes, Webster developed a compellingly original landscape idiom.

4th stop: PACE WIDELSTEIN GALLERY (534 W 25th St) presents: IRVING PENN, PERSONAL WORK


a survey of privately produced, uncommissioned photographs by the iconic American photographer Irving Penn (1917–2009). A companion to Irving Penn: On Assignment, presented by the galleries in 2013, the exhibition and its counterpart collectively offer a retrospective glance at the breadth of achievement of Penn’s legendary seven decade career. 

Probably the most prolific and respected photographer of the 20th century, Irving Penn is celebrated for his innovative commercial imagery and groundbreaking editorial contributions to Condé Nast publications. In addition to his professional assignments, however, Penn pursued a variety of personal projects – such as nudes, self-portraits, signage, moving light portraits, and still lifes of seemingly inconsequential objects – to maintain an artistic balance throughout his career.


5th stop: MARY BOONE GALLERY (541 W 24th St) presents: JUDITH BERNSTEIN, DICKS OF DEATH


 Dicks of Death, a Marine nickname for the processed beef franks included with beans, is so termed for its foul taste and similarity in appearance to male genitalia. The offensively flavored and phallic shaped food is Government Issue, served to soldiers in ready-to-eat rations. Bernstein lifts this term to zero-in on the war-time phallus and to show us how aggression and patriotism is institutionally packaged to fuel political conflict. This exhibition couples Bernstein’s politicized phallic paintings (begun in 1966), Screw Drawings (begin in 1973), and her more recent work Star Spangled Boner. In Union Jack-Off (1967), Bernstein twists red saturated canvas into five bending phalluses. Emerging from a striped ground, these musty and mottled cocks both interrupt and fuse to the traditional patriotic motif. Next to the sexually expressive shapes, Bernstein scrawls “Union Jack-Off on U.S. Policy in Viet.” However, white spew obstructs the yellow colored slogan, an irruption that connects to the artist’s interest in scatological mark making. With each gesture and successive expression, Bernstein merges masculinity and patriotism to reveal how one inflates and supports the other. The works in this exhibition deploy willfully low artistic strategies – kitsch and graffiti – to disrupt any clean image of policy. The continued engagement with screws and cocks closes in on the machinery of the military industrial complex. Central to Bernstein’s work is the morphing of body parts into these political tools. Judith Bernstein is a celebrated artist, whose work has both utilized and undermined strategies of Pop since the 1960s. This exhibition reconsiders her investigation into the blurred distinction between patriotism and masculinity and the absorption of aggression into everyday politics. 

6th stop: BRUCE SILVERSTEIN GALLERY (535 w 24th St) presents: PENELOPE UMBRICO, SILVERY LIGHT


new photographic and video works related to her continued practice of utilizing the limitless archive of photographic images online. This new work investigates projective and reflective light in relation to the history of photography, digital imaging technologies, and the screen as light source.

In the front gallery, Umbrico has installed the video piece Four Photographs of Rays of Sunlight in Grand Central…, a collection of hundreds of iterations the artist found online of the iconic black and white photograph of sun rays through windows at Grand Central Station. Umbrico identified four versions of this original image of Grand Central Station, repeated over multiple websites selling the images as posters or vintage prints, treated with different color filters, cropping, and “watermarks.” For each of these images she attempts to find the attribution, which, on these sites, is as varied as the aesthetic treatments to which the images have been subjected.

In the back gallery, Umbrico turns to the photo-sharing website Flickr to explore how the full moon is photographed and shared. Everyone’s Photos Any License; Screenshot[masked] is a screenshot from her computer of every image tagged “full moon” on Flickr (1,146,034 images total), which Umbrico produced as a single print running the length of the gallery. The individual subjective experience of witnessing and photographing the moon is revealed as a collective practice, seen re-contextualized in its entirety, with new impact and effect.

7th stop: LUHRING AUGUSTINE GALLERY (531 W 24th St) presents: GUIDO van der WERVE, THE PRESENT MOMENT


 three-channel video installation exploring the different states of mind that compose our consciousness, and that we all employ every day to navigate the outer world.  The work is shot against a stark black background in a purely psychological space, featuring three separate groups of individuals, all of whom populate the workings of the artist’s interior mind. As the individuals perform essential and mindfulness tasks, human emotions are put on display and reduced to sheer mechanics, an aspect further explored through the mechanics of the camera and musical composition. The three videos investigate the three levels of consciousness: id, ego, and superego.

The film is strictly structured on several axes of time: days, months, years. There are twelve acts, corresponding to the twelve months of the year. The camera motions (synchronized through all three screens) during each act follow the schematic line drawings of the twelve zodiacal constellations presented at the beginning of each act. The existential mood of the work is made more tender by the musical score written by Guido, a paean written in twelve parts in the twelve major keys; a recording of Guido playing emanates from a player piano in the center of the gallery, a surrogate for the artist in this first film in which he does not physically appear.

*and* ROGER HIORNS, SCULPTURES


The sculptures feature engines coated with the organic compound copper sulphate, a chemical with an unpredictable reactive potential, which Hiorns has employed to transform mass-produced objects into aesthetic entities; a seemingly redemptive gesture exploring the opposition between the natural and man-made. By anthropomorphizing the objects through anatomical references, Hiorns continues to explore the transposable relationship between man and manufactured product in his sculptures, reducing the human figure into representative signs and totems.


8th stop: ANDREW KREPS GALLERY (537 W 22nd St) presents: ROBERT MELEE, SEMI-QUASI-BOWER RECREATIONAL


Melee continues his investigation of the psychology of the everyday. Often incorporating cast-off quotidian items in his works alongside vividly colored poured paint, Melee points towards a melancholy specific to domestic space, one that is derived simultaneously from familiarity, decoration, and otherness.

At the exhibition’s center is Bower Pool, a new installation that envelops the gallery’s architecture. Drawing its name from Bower birds, who construct lavish, colorful nests as part of a mating ritual, Melee’s installation employs a commercially available above ground pool, overturned and surrounding a column. Streamers, party favors, lights, and gold decorations spill out on the floor, representing an obsessive accumulation. While these low-budget materials root the installation in kitsch, they also ground it within a compulsion for embellishment, and its failed transformative quality. Initially overpowering in its scale, upon closer inspection, Bower Pool soon reveals its components for what they are, the deflated markers of celebration.



Bonus/ellective stop: SIKKEMA JENKIND GALLERY (530 W 22nd) presents: POSCARDS FROM THE EDGE, a benefit for VISUAL AIDS ($5.00 donation/admission; we can see this now or at end of tour)

9th stop:  PAULA COOPER GALLERY (521 W 21st St) presents: JONATHAN BOROFSKY, RETROSPECTIVE

painting and sculpture from 1967–1983.


Borofsky came to prominence in the New York art world of the mid-1970s, “hitting the stagnant art scene […] like a blast of crazy, fresh air.”1 In a period dominated by the detached ethos of Minimalism and Conceptualism, the artist developed a highly personal style that emphasized the emotive and fantastical recesses of human consciousness. Among his earliest works are sculptures inspired by his childhood summers in Camp Alton, New Hampshire. These eccentric, mock-devotional objects, one of which is included in the show, frame camp snapshots with cut chipboard and splatter paint.

10th Stop: GLADSTONE GALLERY (530 W 21st St) presents: LARI PITTMAN, NUEVOS CAPRICHOS


In this exhibition of eight large-scale paintings, Pittman pays homage to Los Caprichos, a suite of etchings by Francisco Goya, first published as an album in 1799. In these etchings Goya illustrates the brutality of human behavior to comment on oppressive social conditions in eighteenth century Spanish culture. Pittman offers vignettes in the form of painting as a vehicle to address a broad range of social political issues, updating and renewing Goya’s Caprichos as a contemporary response to increasing levels of violence collectively internalized.

In place of Goya’s staunchly critical voice, Pittman aligns his subjects with language from Emily Dickinson, employing the poet’s voice to express a secular vision of the body, pain, and death. Pittman sees in Dickinson’s proto-feminist writing a secular vehicle to ruminate on larger philosophical issues of contemporary trauma, while not essentializing pain for herself or within her body.

11th stop: GAGOSIAN GALLERY (522 W 21st St) presents: GREGORY CREWDSON, CATHERDRAL OF THE PINES

was made during three productions in and around the rural town of Becket, Massachusetts. In images that recall nineteenth-century American and European paintings, Crewdson photographed figures in the surrounding forests, including the actual trail from which the series takes its title. Interior scenes charged with ambiguous narratives probe tensions between art, life, connection and separation, intimacy and isolation.

The series comprises thirty-one digital pigment prints, each measuring 45 × 58 inches framed. In Woman at Sink, a woman pauses from her household upkeep, lost in thought. In Pickup Truck, Crewdson portrays a nude couple in the flatbed of a truck in a dense forest—the woman seated, the man turned away in repose. Crewdson situates his disconsolate subjects in familiar settings, yet their cryptic actions—standing still in the snow, or nude on a riverbank—hint at invisible challenges. Precisely what these challenges are, and what fate awaits these anonymous figures, are left to the viewer's imagination.

12th stop:  DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (537 W 20th St) presents: DOUG WHEELER, ENCASEMENTS


This exhibition represents the most comprehensive presentation to date of this important body of work, and will comprise five “encasements,” including a rarely seen “center light” work. Presented here in an open configuration, viewers will have the unprecedented opportunity to consider these singular works in relation to one another and to compare the distinct luminous atmospheric effects and subtle tonal variations that characterize each of them. Previously, no more than two encasements have been shown together, as in exhibitions at Fort Worth Art Center Museum, Texas (1969), Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam (1969), and Tate Gallery, London (1970), and accordingly this exhibition aims to underscore their ongoing significance.

A pioneering figure in what is often referred to as the Light and Space movement in Los Angeles during the 1960s and 1970s, Wheeler is noted for his innovative constructions and installations that manipulate the perception and experience of space, volume, and light. First conceived between 1967 and 1969, the artist’s “light encasements” evolved out of his longstanding experimentations with fabricated acrylic and neon, and consist of large panels of vacuum-formed plastic with neon lighting embedded along their inside edges. Installed in a white room with all architectural detail and ambient light eliminated, the light paintings appear to dematerialize, immersing viewers in a luminous space where light seems to have almost particulate mass.

13th Stop: JONATHAN LEVINE GALLERY (529 W 20th St) presents: INTERESNI KAZKI, SACRED GRAVITATION


Interesni Kazki have been painting together for over 15 years and are pioneers of the graffiti movement in Eastern Europe. With an aesthetic that has evolved from traditional graffiti writing to allegorical and figurative compositions, their work invites viewers to consider the spiritual side of the universe. When translated to English their name means Interesting Fairytale. Renowned for their imaginative imagery - inspired by science, religion, mythology, folklore and history - each piece is created in an attempt to look beyond the bounds of what is visible and present a new perception of the world. The new body of work presented in Sacred Gravitation comprises intricately detailed paintings and drawings that merge physical and spiritual elements reflecting on the nature of existence.

*and* DALEK, THE REDISTRIBUTION OF DESTRUCTION


marks Marshall’s return to the New York art world after a five year hiatus during which he perfected a purely abstract aesthetic. Bold, flat colors form planes of space that are impeccably separated by precise geometric line-work. Giving the impression of movement, his pairing of vivid shades evoke a three-dimensional depth and engages viewers with varying optical perspectives.

Marshall’s work has significantly evolved since his debut solo show at the gallery back in 2007. At the time he was known solely as Dalek and his iconic Space Monkey, a mischievous character born out of graffiti, was featured in every vibrant composition. By 2010, he dropped the Dalek moniker to reveal his true name and debuted paintings that reduced the Space Monkey and his surroundings to their basic underlying linear components.

14th stop: ANTORN KERN GALLERY (532 W 20th) presents: FRANCIS UPRITCHARD & MARTINO GAMPER, INSTALLATION


Wife and husband and frequent collaborators, Francis Upritchard and Martino Gamper bring together contrasting approaches to the making of three-dimensional objects. Upritchard is a sculptress from New Zealand with an extensive history of museum and gallery exhibitions, and Gamper an Italian designer with a wide and fascinating array of design exhibitions and commissions.

Their first joint exhibition at the gallery will blend sculpture and furniture in such a seamless way that genre or category seems temporarily thrown overboard. Upritchard and Gamper play with ideas of origin and derivation by combining figures, artifacts and pseudo-anthropological objects with newly designed as well as re-appropriated furniture, denying every concept of cultural purity and authenticity. 

15th Stop: DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (533 W 19th St) presents: MARCEL DZAMA and  RAYMOND PETTIBON, FORGETTING THE HAND


 this is the first time the pair has worked together. The drawings were originally created for a zine published by David Zwirner Books to coincide with Printed Matter’s New York Art Book Fair at MoMA PS1 (September 2015).

The collaboration began in Summer 2015 with the artists swapping the first of a series of drawings to be completed by the other. In a variation of the “exquisite corpse” method in which a partner is only given portions of an otherwise concealed drawing to work on, Dzama and Pettibon developed each other’s compositions through illustrations, collage, and writing. Just as the surrealists invented the technique in the early twentieth century as a playful and ultimately enriching exercise, the present drawings combine the two artists’ distinct styles in a revealing and often seamless fashion. In several works, it is almost impossible to determine who made what, which indicates how both strove to assimilate the other’s vision or anticipate his response.

16th stop: DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (525 W 19th St) presents: YUTAKA SONE, DAY AND NIGHT 


Sone’s work revolves around a tension between realism and perfection. A conceptual framework, paired with a meticulous attention to detail, has characterized his practice since the early 1990s, informing equally his self-contained jungle environments, life-size roller coasters, magnified snowflakes, and staged events. His sculptural works in particular attest to a profound interest in landscapes, whether natural or architectural, and their extraordinary ability to capture light relates them to a genre primarily associated with painting and photography.

The exhibition features a new group of canvases depicting scenes at night. The motifs were taken from the artist’s large-scale, white marble sculptures and respectively show an amusement park roller coaster, Los Angeles highway intersection, and Hong Kong and Manhattan cityscapes. With their black backdrops illuminated by brightly painted artificial lights, the paintings contrast with the purity of their sculptural counterparts, yet similarly present their subjects as archetypal landscapes somehow unaffected by the life that circulates within them.

The marble sculpture Movie Theater (2013) continues Sone’s interest in rendering light in three dimensions. For his earlier Light in between Trees series (2010), shards of light surrounding snowcapped trees or stumps were given physical form, welding abstract and figurative shapes. Here, a beam emerging from a projection window materializes into a large triangular geometrical object hovering over the audience as a roof.

Also on view are life-sized sculptures of palm trees, which embody the ongoing dialogue within Sone’s oeuvre between natural and man-made structures. 

FEE: $5.00 for regular members; FREE for full-paid members!

Let’s photograph skating in not just one, but BOTH of Manhattan’s cinematically historic ice skating rinks.


We’ll meet at Wollman Rink in Central Park, the location of several movies and tv shows, including Serendipity, Love Story, and Gossip Girl. We’ll photography the skaters against the dramatic backdrop of skyscraping buildings to the south. While we’re there, can also shoot nearby attractions, such as The Carousel, Gapstow Bridge, and even pass through the The Zoo. 

We’ll then head out of the Park near the Plaza Hotel, and either walk or subway down to Rockefeller Center to photograph the famous rink there (remember Will Ferrel and Zooey Deschanel skating there in Elf?) That will also give us a chance to shoot the Channel Gardens and lots of interesting architectural detail at Rockefeller Center. 

Finally, by 3:30 pm or so, those who wish to join us will partake in the traditional After-The-Meetup meal/snack...we’ll find someplace in the Lower Plaza of Rockefeller Center - there's lots to choose from there.

results.description:
World of Wings strives to teach children the value of life and introduce them to the wonders of the natural world through its butterfly atrium and museum. Paths wind through an oasis of waterfalls, tropical plants, chirping birds, and nectar flowers, which provide food for the hundreds of Lepidoptera fluttering inside the glass enclosure. Knowledgeable staffers are on-hand to explain to visitors why butterflies exhibit certain behaviors, such as puddling (butterflies drink from muddy puddles when they need minerals and there's no San Pellegrino around).

In the museum, guests can visit with amphibians and reptiles, observe the process of preserving delicate insects, and peek in the butterfly nursery. Staffers move winged beauties from the nursery into the atrium once a day, letting new butterflies experience their first flight in full view of visitors. For fun with slightly less science, kids can scale a climbing wall, go nuts in a bounce room, visit the ocean-like bubble room, and have their eyes tricked in the illusion room. Please see groupon: https://www.groupon.com/deals/world-of-wings-1-10
results.name: Go to World of Wings

results.description:
As with all SDI programs, you’ll learn to dive Nitrox the modern way, using a Nitro-programmable dive computer instead of arcane formulas and complicated tables.

EZ Nitrox was developed to introduce even the newest of divers to NITROX Diving

Enroll now to get started with on-line academics which need to be completed before this session. 
When you come to the Dive Center we will review the academics and do the practical application session. Here you will get hands-on experience on how to

Analyze: You need to know how to analyze to ensure the proper and safest FO2 for your dive.

Label: Know what to and how to properly mark on your cylinder.

Log: Fill out the blenders log to ensure you get the percentages you asked for.

+: Program a dive computer for Nitrox

Working with an Oxygen analyzer and Dive computer will prepare you to maximize the benefits of Nitrox diving to meet your diving needs.

Pr-registration is required. For more info call[masked]

The SDI OnLine Computer Nitrox course is a great next step after 
the Open Water Diver certification and is structured in an easy to understand manner by making use of a Nitrox programmable computer. Nitrox as a breathing gas has a lot of benefits for both new and experienced. The course will cover the use of Nitrox mixtures from 22 to 40 percent oxygen.

The benefits of using Nitrox include 
* Increased safety margins 
* Reduced post dive fatigue 
* Extended no-decompression times

When you have completed the academic review and practical application sessions, we will will process your permanent certification card. What could be easier? Nitrox opens a world of possibilities, leading to better, more enjoyable diving. What are you waiting for?

Pre-registration required. Cost $148 ea. Pay Now  includes the eLearning codes and the practical session. 

C-Card processing and registration is $34

Refresher $29.95 (proof of cert required)

Pay now and I'll email you the access code to start the online academics

Optional Openwater dives can be conducted at Dutch Springs or on one of our Dive Trips

The greatest benefits of Nitrox are found between 0 and 130 feet, and require just a little more training and experience. Nitrox is another tool for divers to use. It is not designed to replace air. Nitrox is ideal for recreational diving. You can gain a safety advantage OR longer bottom times using Nitrox. In either case, many divers report less fatigue and a sense of well-being after Nitrox dives. 
In addition to feeling better after diving, the decrease of of nitrogen accumulation also allows:

Increased safety margins when using dive computers.

A significant increase in bottom time no-decompression limits when using Nitrox tables.

A reduction of decompression time if the no-decompression limits are exceeded.

A reduction of possible decompression illness.

Reduces the effects of Nitrogen Narcosis.


What is Nitrox? 
Nitrox is simply any mixture of oxygen and nitrogen. Air is made up of 21% oxygen and 79% nitrogen. The name "Nitrox" usually refers to oxygen-nitrogen mixtures containing more than 21% oxygen. Other names for this gas are EANx, Enriched Air Nitrox and Safe Air. There are two standard Nitrox mixtures. Nitrox containing 32% oxygen and Nitrox containing 36% oxygen.

Why should I use Nitrox? 
The main benefit to diving with Nitrox is the reduced amount of nitrogen in your breathing gas. Less nitrogen means less risk of getting decompression sickness (DCS), or "the bends". Using Nitrox can also extend your bottom time. Because no-decompression limits are based on nitrogen absorption, less nitrogen means more bottom time. Many divers also claim that they feel less fatigued after diving with Nitrox (as compared to diving with air).

Why do I need a Nitrox Course? 
Nitrox, like all other breathing gases (including air), has its safe limits at depth so it is very important to know and understand these limits before you make your first Nitrox dive. You will also need a Nitrox Certification card to purchase mixed gases. To fully understand the benefits of using Nitrox it is important to receive proper training. Classroom sessions include information on the theory of diving Nitrox, blending, dive tables, gas analyzing and dive planning. Upon completion you will receive your certification allowing you to use Nitrox for all your diving adventures.

In addition to feeling better after diving, the decrease of of nitrogen accumulation also allows: 
- Increased safety margins when using computers. 
- A significant increase in bottom time no-decompression limits when using Dive Computer Nitrox plan. 
- A reduction of possible decompression illness. 
- A reduction of decompression time if the no-decompression limits are exceeded. 
- Reduces the effects of Nitrogen Narcosis.

Nitrox Equipment 
Most of your regular scuba equipment will work without modification for use with Nitrox. Your regulator, pressure hoses and other equipment will work just fine.

results.description:
IN JACKSON HEIGHTS, a three-hour documentary by Frederick Wiseman, offers cross section of the multicultural neighborhood, Jackson Heights.


Jackson Heights, Queens is one of the most culturally diverse communities in the US where 167 languages are spoken. IN JACKSON HEIGHTS explores the conflict between maintaining ties to old traditions and adapting to American values.

BUY TICKETS 


Tickets are $10 and include an all day pass to the museum! Order tickets online, and enter the code CIANA at checkout for discount. Tickets must be picked up 10 minutes prior to event start time.


IN JACKSON HEIGHTS
Frederick Wiseman, 190 mins, 2015

https://vimeo.com/141051231


New York Times Review: “CRITIC’S PICK. A thrilling, transporting love letter from Frederick Wiseman to New York and its multi-everything glory… A movingly principled, political look at a dynamic neighborhood… An epic of a city, its people and the democratic process… By the time fireworks are soaring, your heart is, too.”
results.name: In Jackson Heights

Outline

results.description:
Have you ever wonder Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business? 

http://charlesduhigg.com/the-power-of-habit/

"A young woman walks into a laboratory. Over the past two years, she has transformed almost every aspect of her life. She has quit smoking, run a marathon, and been promoted at work. The patterns inside her brain, neurologists discover, have fundamentally changed.

Marketers at Procter & Gamble study videos of people making their beds. They are desperately trying to figure out how to sell a new product called Febreze, on track to be one of the biggest flops in company history. Suddenly, one of them detects a nearly imperceptible pattern—and with a slight shift in advertising, Febreze goes on to earn a billion dollars a year.

An untested CEO takes over one of the largest companies in America. His first order of business is attacking a single pattern among his employees—how they approach worker safety—and soon the firm, Alcoa, becomes the top performer in the Dow Jones.

What do all these people have in common? They achieved success by focusing on the patterns that shape every aspect of our lives.

They succeeded by transforming habits.

In The Power of Habit, award-winning New York Times business reporter Charles Duhigg takes us to the thrilling edge of scientific discoveries that explain why habits exist and how they can be changed. With penetrating intelligence and an ability to distill vast amounts of information into engrossing narratives, Duhigg brings to life a whole new understanding of human nature and its potential for transformation.

Along the way we learn why some people and companies struggle to change, despite years of trying, while others seem to remake themselves overnight. We visit laboratories where neuroscientists explore how habits work and where, exactly, they reside in our brains. We discover how the right habits were crucial to the success of Olympic swimmer Michael Phelps, Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz, and civil-rights hero Martin Luther King, Jr. We go inside Procter & Gamble, Target superstores, Rick Warren’s Saddleback Church, NFL locker rooms, and the nation’s largest hospitals and see how implementing so-called keystone habits can earn billions and mean the difference between failure and success, life and death.

At its core, The Power of Habit contains an exhilarating argument: The key to exercising regularly, losing weight, raising exceptional children, becoming more productive, building revolutionary companies and social movements, and achieving success is understanding how habits work.

Habits aren’t destiny. As Charles Duhigg shows, by harnessing this new science, we can transform our businesses, our communities, and our lives." 

-From charlesduhigg.com

You can also find this book at 

http://www.amazon.com/The-Power-Habit-What-Business/dp/081298160X

UPDATES: 

Agenda

2pm-2:15pm Meet and Greet/ Socialize (feel free to grab some drinks or snacks from the coffee stand in the atrium or bring your own food; I might bake some cookies but no guarantee…) 

2:15pm-2:30pm A Brief Introduction/ Summary of the Book 

2:30pm-3:30pm Book Discussion (please see the questions post below) 

3:30pm-4pm Wrap-up/ Socialize 

Book Discussion Questions: 

1) The author writes that it is possible to reawaken a habit, and that habits never disappear, but are changed by new cues, routines, or rewards. Describe a habit of yours that has been changed or replaced. Do you agree or disagree that this habit can be reawakened? Why? What would it take to reawaken your habit? 

2) The chapter breaks down several behaviors into habit loops, including running, eating, and cleaning. Think about how you exercise, eat, or clean. What are your cues, rewards, and cravings for these activities? Which ones are the same and which ones are different from those described in the chapter? 

3) Why are habits so hard to change? Think about a time when you have tried to change one of your habits. Was it hard? Were you successful? If so, how did you do it? If not, what should you have done differently? 

4) Can individuals change their habits without the support of a group? 

5) What are keystone habits? What are some keystone habits in your life/organizations/ companies you are a part of? Are there any you would like to change? Why are keystone habits important? How do they become meaningful? 

6) Can you recognize shopping habits in yourself? Do you turn right most often in the grocery store? Do you purchase your veggies first and junk food later on during a shopping trip? Had you ever thought about your grocery habits before? 


7) Ironically, when marketers manipulate human behavior to earn profits, it is considered an achievement of capitalism. However, if a psychologist manipulates human behavior to study the process of decision making, it might be considered unethical. Why don’t advertisers and marketers need to abide by the same ethical standards when it comes to manipulation of behavior? Is it ethical for corporations to collect data about your shopping habits without your consent? Why or why not? 

Special Thanks to SF book club's organizer, Anabel H, as a mentor coaching and guiding me on organizing our first Meetup!

** This three week intensive workshop is for anyone who has at least once attended my Basic Improv for Public Speaking class. **

** Please wear sneakers and BRING WATER. **

** DOOR CLOSES at 2:15 p.m., and entrance will NOT be guaranteed after that time, so please be on time. **

NOTE: By RSVPing to this event you are committing to THREE consecutive Saturday afternoon classes.

Class One:  Saturday, January 30

Class Two: Saturday, February 6

**********************************************

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

results.description:
"You may have the universe, if I may have Italy." - Giuseppe Verdi


Anyone who is familiar with Italy -- its glorious architecture, epic history, exquisite fine arts, and majestic landscape -- understands Verdi's passionate words above. For centuries, Italy has been an irresistible magnet for people from all corners of the world, attracting the most illustrious men and women of every age, as well as visitors from every walk of life. Today, it remains a  special  mecca, uplifting, fascinating, and enchanting all.


Renowned Italian Scholar Joseph Luzzi is presenting a remarkable 2.5 hour class on a whirlwind tour of Italy's "greatest cultural hits" in order to explore the fascinating world of Italian art, music, film, architecture, literature, and even food and wine!  We will learn how Italy has been a "grand tour" travel destination for centuries as we discover the fine art of living Italian style.

************************************************************* 
Cost and Registration:  The full price of this class is $79, but by using the coupon code below you can register for only $59 (and the price includes wine).  Click here to register.   Use code ITALY 

***********************************************************

Dinner: If you would be interested in an early dinner following the event, please leave a note in the comments section.  If enough people want to go, I will make a reservation at Il Mulino, a few blocks away.  <a>http://www. ilmulino.com</a>

*************************************************************

Transportation: When we get closer to the date, I will post the train schedule for those who would like to travel in to Penn Station together and then take the subway downtown.  The Center is about 2 blocks from the subway station.

**************************************************************

About the Presenter:  Joseph Luzzi is a Literature and Italian Professor at Bard College, and was previously a Visiting Professor at the University of Pennsylvania, where he received the Scallion Prize for Italian Studies.  Professor Luzzi has also taught at Yale University where he was awarded a Yale College Teaching Prize and is the author of numerous books including the bestselling "My Two Italies."

Let's ice skate at Riverbank State Park where there is a big outdoor, yet covered ice rink open to the public.  The rink is bigger than that of Bryant Park, Rockefeller and Lasker and therefore it is better (not to mention cheaper) to execute your triple salchow-double axel combinations, cross overs and forward swizzels at this ice rink or simply just practice and learn the basics.  


Admission is $5.  If you have skates, bring them, else they are $6 to rent.  They have lockers there for your shoes and accessories.  

To get to Riverbank State Park Ice Rink, take the 1 train to 145th street, then walk west on W145th Street towards the Hudson River.  You'll go through the park entrance where the road will lead you to the left.  Continue following road and you will see the big ice skating rink. 

When you get there at 2pm, you will pay for your admission and then head to the dressing/locker area where the skate rentals are.  We can convene there and get on the ice between 2:15 and 2:30.  If you come later, just find us on the ice; we shouldn’t be difficult to spot; I will likely be wearing a royal blue/azure coloured coat and my Bauer brand hockey skates.

The plan is to skate from 2:15pm until about 4:30 and then for those interested in grabbing a beer, head over to the bar Harlem Public for drinks.  Harlem Public is located at 3612 Broadway, between W148th and W149th Streets, just a few blocks north of 145th Street Station. 

Happy skating!
results.how_to_find_us: 2-2:30 in the locker room/dressing area; after that on the ice.
results.name: The "Everything is bigger in Harlem" Ice Skate

results.description:
Natural Historians,

Please join us for our 2016 kickoff event, Dinosaur Hall Tour with paleontologist Danny Barta on Saturday, Jan 30 at 2 PM at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH). Come hear from dinosaur expert Danny Barta about the evolution of dinosaurs, and the hypotheses concerning their end and their evolution into the birds around us today. Learn and see the differences between the two major groups of dinosaurs: ornithischians and saurischians and listen to Barta describe his own research on dinosaur reproduction, growth and development. Our event is just in time for seeing the latest addition to the AMNH's exhibit, Titanosaur, a 120 ft long dinosaur from Argentina.

Danny Barta is a Ph.D. candidate in comparative biology at the Richard Gilder Graduate School of the American Museum of Natural History. He grew up in Helena, Montana, and holds a masters degree in earth sciences from Montana State University. Broadly, he is interested in vertebrate reproduction, growth, and development. His doctoral research focuses on the post-hatching growth and development of basal theropod and ornithischian dinosaurs. The exceptional collections available at the American Museum of Natural History can provide important insight into dinosaur growth rates and anatomical changes during development. He also has conducted fieldwork in the western United States, China, and Mongolia. 

This event is FREE! However, we have a limited number of spaces available. In order to register for this event, you MUST send an email to [masked].
NB: ONLY CONFIRMED PARTICIPANTS WILL BE ALLOWED TO ATTEND THIS EVENT. Facebook and Meetup "attendance" will not be considered as registration.

For all confirmed attendees, please meet on the 2nd floor Theodore Roosevelt Rotunda of the American Museum of Natural History. To reach the rotunda, enter through the main entrance of the AMNH on Central Park West and wait underneath the dinosaurs (Barosaurus and Allosaurus). If you have trouble finding us please call, (917) 975-0392.

Feel free to contact us if you have any questions.

The Officers of the MSNH
results.name: NOW FULL!!!!: 2016 Kickoff Event: Dinosaur Hall Tour at AMNH

results.description:
We had so much fun at this meetup last winter that I decided then it should be an annual event. The holidays may be over but winter in New York maintains its own seasonal charms so we'll take in some classic Old New York Bars in the Gramercy area.


We'll start the day off at Molly's Shebeen, arguably New York's most traditional Irish pub. Molly's was opened in 1960 in a building that first opened as a bar in 1895. Its rustic Irish cottage theme, which dates to 1964, features sawdust on the floor and a wood-burning fireplace. Both the fireplace and the Honduran mahogany bar date to Molly's original late-19th century incarnation.


Irish folk band The Clancy Brothers and Irish writer Brendan Behan were regulars here in Molly's early days. Singer Diana Krall wrote several of her songs from a booth here. 

From there, we'll proceed half a block down 3rd Avenue to Rolf's German Restaurant. Rolf's has been a Gramercy Park fixture since 1968, when it was opened by Rolf Hoffman. Gramercy Park was a German neighborhood for many years. But it wasn't until Bob Maisano and Ben House  took over the place after Hoffman's death in 1981 that Christmas at Rolf's started to become a New York City tradition. They started small with decorations found at any discount store. But every year they added more and more and eventually replaced the dime-store decorations with high-end ornaments bought from New England antique stores. House passed away in 1996, but Maisano has continued the tradition.


It's not Christmas time anymore but Rolf's is still a Black Forest Winter Wonderland this time of year.


After Rolf's we'll head towards Union Square to visit two of New York's best old bars: Pete's Tavern and the Old Town Bar.

Pete's opened in 1864 as the Portman Hotel in a building that dates to 1829. Establishments that served alcohol have been on the premises since 1852. The famous bar has been part of the set of countless movies and TV shows including "Ragtime", "Endless Love", "Law & Order" and "Sex and the City", as well as several beer commercials, including many of the famous Miller Lite commercials of the 1970s and '80s.


The bar became known as Healy's in 1899 when it was bought by Tom and John Healy. The great American writer O. Henry was a regular around this time and wrote his 1906 Christmas short story "The Gift of the Magi" in Booth 3 at Healy's. Ludwig Bemelmans wrote "Madeline" here as well. The opening lines of the book were originally written on the back of a Healy's menu.

Pete Belles acquired the bar from the Healys in the early 1920s and it's been known as Pete's Tavern ever since despite several ownership changes. Pete's stayed open during Prohibition by operating a flower shop in the front of the bar while the saloon continued in the back. Joe Kennedy provided the bootlegged alcohol. Years after Prohibition ended, Kennedy's son Jack and daughter-in-law Jacqueline became regulars.


We'll cap off our Winter Gramercy Park Old New York bar tour at the Old Town Bar. Like Pete's, the Old Town is one of those quintessential New York bars that's starred in movies and TV shows of its own including "The Devil's Own", and "The Last Days of Disco." It was also featured in the opening of the original "Late Night with David Letterman" TV show and was the setting for Riff's Bar in the TV show "Mad About You."

The Old Town opened in 1892 as a German restaurant called Viemaster's, which had a men-only bar downstairs and a family dining room upstairs. After surviving Prohibition as a restaurant that secretly served alcohol (if there was a raid, customers would stash booze under the seats in the booths, which still open up to this day), the bar took on its current moniker in 1933. The Old Town remains largely unchanged from its late 19th-century days, with original tile floor, frosted glass doors and mahogany bar. Like Pete's, it has a literary tradition of its own. Contemporary writers like Frank McCourt, Seamus Heaney, Thomas Kelly and Jim Dwyer have been regulars here over the years. The bar has an irreverent sense of humor about itself. In 2010, it celebrated the 100th anniversary of the massive Hinsdale urinals in its men's room.

Should be a fun day, hopefully monsoon rains don't wash it out. A little snow wouldn't be a bad thing though.

See you there!

results.description:
In partnership with Untapped Cities I am excited to offer this new, exclusive private group tour of the normally off-limits Woolworth Building led by building architect Cass Gilbert’s great granddaughter, <a>Helen Post Curry</a>, who runs the Woolworth Building tours. In addition to a guided visit through the spectacular lobby, we will also visit the cellar level where the bank vault is located and where the former entrances to the subway are, and provide special access to the gorgeous mezzanine level. 

Photography is permitted inside the Woolworth Building.  Note cost is $35.00 per person payable in advance via our meetup site in order to RSVP which also includes the neighborhood walking tour. This price is a $10.00 discount from the normally $45.00 per person.   Note there is a limit of 20 people for this special tour.  I cannot have a waiting list for a pre-paid tour so if all 20 spots are taken and you are interested send me a message and I will create a manual waiting list.

The Woolworth Building visit starts at 4:00pm and ends by 5:00pm.  Prior to this experience at 2:30pm we'll gather for a 75-minute guided walking tour of the surrounding area (led by me) starting at 2:30pm  through part of Tribeca and the Civic Center.  


Cass Gilbert was Curry’s paternal great grandfather and she began running tours in the Woolworth Building on the 100th anniversary of the landmark. As Curry says herself, “there are so many behind-the-scenes “secrets” about the Woolworth Building” and we’re excited to share them with you on this special, insiders tour.  The Woolworth Building, designed in the neo-gothic style is referred to as "The Cathedral of Commerce" is considered one of the most beautiful skyscrapers and was the world's tallest building from 1913-1929. 


Note: I will email people one week before the tour to see who would like to meet for brunch beforehand at 1:00pm.

Thanks from Hank

[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: This Starbucks is located in the ground floor of the Woolworth Building at near Barclay Street:  Subways: 2,3 to Park Place; R or N to City Hall; A or C  to Chambers Street; 4,5,6 to Brooklyn Bridge or Fulton Street.
results.name: *Special* Insiders Tour of the Woolworth Building + a Guided Neighborhood Tour!

results.description:
This is my second year attending this valuable program. Under Lee Reiser, ACA level ll instructor, will help you hone your existing skills, learn new ones properly and introduce new people to the world of kayaking. In a beautiful heated pool with all kayaks and gear provided you can train for 2 hours learning bracing, rolling, rescues etc. and in return help the public for 2 hours by setting up and putting equipment away, greeting the public students, assisting instructors etc. All level of kayakers are welcome. The sessions are as follows:
Course 1 Saturday - Nov. 14,21; Dec. 5, 12 (completed)
Course 2 " - Jan. 9, 16, 23, 30
Course 3 " - Feb. 6, 13, 27; March 5
The time for volunteers to practice is from 3 to 4 pm and the time to volunteer is from 4 to 6 pm. Please arrive at least 15 minutes before so you can get ready. Pack a small bag with your change of clothes. The pool is heated but you may want to wear a wet suit, bringing your own PFD, paddle and skirt can add to your comfort level. Pack a small bag with a change of clothes, towel etc and bring a lock for the lockers.
Please fill out the volunteer packet which can be obtained from the Yonkers Club site: http://www.yprc.org
click on the Riverbank link once you are in the site and download the NY community Kayak Program packet. If you commit to at least 1 session you will be provided with a parking pass.

DIRECTIONS- From 138th St. head west and make a left onto 12th Ave., Take the 1st right beneath the West Side Hwy (by the restaurant) then swing right again past the first guard booth. Follow the roadway in and around, curve left and make a hard left U-turn into the parking area. Use the elevator to get to the park on the upper level walk to the pool area. Make sure you have a parking permit in your car window. Please car pool as parking is limited.

SEE NOV. 21, 2015 FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON THESE ONGOING CLASSES.
results.name: Volunteer, learn new skills and kayak at the NY Community Kayak Program.

results.description:
Under Lee Reiser, ACA level ll instructor, will help you hone your existing skills, learn new ones properly and introduce new people to the world of kayaking. In a beautiful heated pool with all kayaks and gear provided you can train for 2 hours learning bracing, rolling, rescues etc. and in return help the public for 2 hours by setting up and putting equipment away, greeting the public students, assisting instructors etc. All level of kayakers are welcome.

The sessions are as follows:
Course 1 Saturday - Nov. 14, 21; Dec. 5, 12, 2015
Course 2 " - Jan. 9, 16, 23, 30, 2016
Course 3 " - Feb. 6, 13, 27; March 5, 2016

Spots are limited to 8 HVH members per session !


  The time for volunteers to practice is from 3 to 4 pm, and the time to volunteer is from 4 to 6 pm. Please arrive at least 15 minutes before so you can get ready. Pack a small bag with your change of clothes. The pool is heated but you may want to wear a wet suit, bringing your own PFD, paddle and skirt can add to your comfort level. Nose, ear plugs and goggles are helpful for rolling practice.  Pack a small bag with a change of clothes, towel etc. and bring a lock for the lockers.


Please fill out the volunteer packet which can be obtained from the Yonkers Club site: http://www.yprc.org
click on the Riverbank link once you are in the site and download the NY community Kayak Program packet. If you commit to at least 1 session you will be provided with a parking pass. If you are attending contact Audrey Jackson, Program Coordinator at:  [masked]


Parking & Direction


- From Broadway, take West 145 street all the way to the Guard at the booth of 145 street & RiverSide drive.

- Let the Guard knows that you need to get the parking permit and instruction to get to the pool and he will give you a parking slip with all instruction where to park and how to get to the pool.

- After, you will need to go back to Broadway and make right then another right on West 138 Street. Take it all the way to the end and make left at the stop sign. Then continue until you get another stop sign and make right. Go under the bridge and make your first right.

- You will go through another Guard Booth and stay to your right and follow the curve and you will see the parking lot on your left.

- Take the elevator to the top and stay on your right to find the pool


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review maps and water features carefully; understanding conditions of any trip is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. Capsizing is always a possibility when engaged in a paddling trip, be mentally prepared and know how to swim and self-rescue before going on any paddling trip.

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a paddling trip (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike/paddle signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.
Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
Message from JOHN:

As soon as 4 photographers RSVP in this group and pay, The event will be closed to additional RSVP's. -- Though Maximum attendance is 6, I don;t want to overbook with the other groups attendance.  (Model ratio 1: 2 photographers) Between our Brooklyn group and Manhattan group there are 3 photographers attending (as of Wed, 1/27). If 1 additional photographer attends, I will come to support Monica and be there for technical assistance for all. I'll also bring my speed lights with triggers for members to borrow if they wish. 

Makeup session is from 3-4 ~ Attending photographers are welcome to shoot during the makeup session. As well as shoot the models waiting for their makeup session.  This makeup time is ideal to use as practice shooting for composition, exposure, posing and lens choice.  

Monica is putting together some pretty great events, many members here have never been to a model shoot.  This group is unique in that models are  the host as well. They actively interact with the photographers helping them with ideas that will result in great images. 

A big THANK YOU!  to Monica, she's been really working hard to make this group unique and special!  

On an additional side note, Keep in mine how much these girls are getting paid.  Add it all up and think how it's distributed with 3 models and a makeup artist. for their time at the shoot, the prep and travel time and you will come to realize That you are getting a great bargain!   This is their profession, it's not a hobby.  We all should be thankful that they have been working with WCM and have been willing reduce their rates to make the events affordable to many in the group.  With that being said, I encourage all of you to tip the models as you see fit. 

~John

=================================

Theme:

Don't miss this once in a lifetime opportunity - shoot 3 models. One fair skin toned (Vivian), one tan/olive skin toned (me), one dark rich ebony skin toned (Dorkys). PICTURES OF GUEST MODELS BELOW! It's going to be an epic shoot. Professional makeup artist included.

Models:

Vivian:

Monica:

Dorkys:

Location:

Penn station has some amazing tile murals by the entrance to the A subway line.

Price:


$77 + $12 booking fee = $89

The price includes 3 models and a professional mua who will be on-site doing makeup from 3-4 pm. She is AMAZING and her rates are normally $200/hour, but she is discounting her price for me because we are friends. Photoshoot with models will commence after makeup is finished, around 4 pm. 

1 hour makeup, 2 hour photoshoot.

results.description:
REMINDER FOR TOMORROW:  We now have 20 YES rsvps, which is great, but I need to know if that many are ACTUALLY coming.Can you do me a favor, and if you can no longer make it, please change your rsvp to No? This would be so helpful so I can make the proper arrangements with the restaurant. They may not have a table for 20, so we may have to do two tables near/next to each other of 10 instead. Just please be there on time so we can be seated, and please be aware that this restaurant has a $25 per person minimum for large parties. Bring cash if you can so the bill is easier to do at the end. Im going to send private messages to all Yes rsvps with my cell #. PLEASE contact me via cell/text tomorrow with any issues or cancellations, as I wont be able to check this site once I leave my apartment. If we have to split into 2 tables, hopefully after lunch, we can talk a bit outside or somewhere nearby, just so we can ALL get to know each other a bit more. I look forward to seeing/meeting all of you! 

RESCHEDULING DUE TO PENDING SNOWSTORM: 

Sorry to keep changing this guys, but I cant control the weather. NYC area is expecting 6-12 inches tomorrow, supposedly, and some of you have already told me you wont be able to make it out in those conditions.  I think its better to change it to next Saturday and hope for the best with weather.  Please update your RSVP and let me know if you can still come, and please keep me updated if you need to cancel. This restaurant has a $25 per person minimum for large parties, so I NEED to know if people are coming or not. If you can, try to bring cash to make the bill easier. We usually just do the math and everyone pays whatever they owe. Looking forward to seeing you and meeting the ones coming for the first time. THIS WILL HAPPEN, eventually lol. 

DATE CHANGED TO 1/30 due to unforeseen circumstances. 

So sorry everyone. A few weeks ago, my mom was diagnosed with uteran cancer.  I came to Massachusetts, where they live, to stay with them over the holidays, and Im still here. Her hysterectomy surgery is tomorrow, Jan 12th, and I am staying here for another week or so to help out with her recovery. So, Im not baack in NY yet and wont be back in time for this meetup date. WHen I scheduled it, I didnt know I would be out of NY for so long, but that is what has happened. Its been a hard month. I hope that most of you can join us on the new date. 

Join us for delicious food, drinks, and great company with others who "get it". We are taking an extended break over the holidays, because I will be out of town for about 3 weeks in Massachusetts with my parents, so this will be our next gathering, and our first one of the New Year. Hope you will join us for the first hang out of 2016!

results.description:
We'll resume our regular monthly meetup, discussing the most compelling and important issues unfolding in our City, the Nation, and around the World.


This month's theme: "Presidential Primary Politics."


Topics:

• Local: interpreting and analyzing the meaning of "New York Values" -- as invoked in one of the recent GOP debates.  Also, Mayor Bloomberg's yet another flirtations for his possible Presidential bid -- is this yet another media buzz that amounts to no tangible outcome?

• National: the state of the 2016 Presidential race, on the eve of the first-in-the-nation election contest.

• World: foreign policy positions for the major Presidential candidates.

*** Also, if time permits, we'll discuss the water crisis in Flint, Michigan..
results.name: January Monthly Meetup — two days until the Iowa Caucuses!

results.description:
FYI, astrologically speaking, the new year is in the spring...


With that being said, our next meetup will consist of us SiStars coming together and creating vision boards for how we personally would like 2016 to go for us; what we see it entailing, and/or what we see it revealing. Everyone should bring at least 1 magazine, and a board of some sort with which you can canvas your vision.

After we complete our vision boards, we will take what we've designed for the coming year, and compare it to what our charts say is in store!

Feel free to bring other crafts and/or utensils (scissors, glue, tape, colored pencils, etc.) that we can use to spruce up our boards. So that there's a fair assortment of everything, write what you're going to bring in the comments. Snacks are also encouraged so feel free to bring something to eat or drink!


This meetup will be held at my house, so I will email those who RSVP individually a day or two before with specifics as to where I live.

I hope to see you there and have a happy holiday!!
results.name: "New" Year Vision Boards!

We're back! Welcome to Season 6 of the NA League of Legends Championship series! Come enjoy the action with us at Playwright Pub! The top floor will be open to everyone (since it's also serves delicious food), so bring your friends! Just make sure that if you're underaged, you do not drink. It's illegal. And please tip your servers!

SCHEDULE (times are approximate):

3PM: TIP v DIG
4PM: C9 v TSM
5PM: TL v NRG
6PM: CLG v FOX
7PM: IMT v REN

We've got bar specials! All Well Mixers and select domestic draft beers are $5! This time we have food! Check out these hearty meals for $10:
Wings and French fries
Sliders and French fries
Buff chicken wrap and fries
Nachos
Yum!

Don't follow esports? No problem, tons of us will be around to get you acquainted with the teams! New to League? Welcome to the party! We all love the game and love new friends!

Looking for people to play fantasy with? We love to theorycraft and welcome your bold predictions!

Join us on the first day of the NA season for good food, good friends, and good games!

With love, League of Libations. ♥

results.description:
Prepay here:

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=YV6TVKQ4ETZP6 

=============================================

The Tenth Annual Master Drawings New York is an event that gives top U.S. and foreign dealers in drawings and watercolors an opportunity to show their best acquisitions to individual and institutional buyers and scholars. The items exhibited at the participating galleries will range from 16th century Old Masters to contemporary works, some newly discovered or not displayed publicly for many years, and will include pencil, ink, chalk, pastel and charcoal drawings, as well as oil on paper sketches and watercolors.

The tour will be led by Savona Bailey-McClain, founder and executive director of the West Harlem Art Fund, an organization that promotes art and culture in parks and other open spaces across NYC, as well as galleries. She has been involved in numerous public art installations and was recently selected to join TINA, a new international network for contemporary art curators based in Italy. In addition, she hosts "State of the Arts NYC", a weekly radio program airing Fridays on WBAI, 99.5 FM. 

IMPORTANT:

- Prepay here:

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=YV6TVKQ4ETZP6 

- If you tried to use the above link but had trouble with Paypal, an alternate payment link on Brown Paper Tickets will be emailed upon request. This will require an extra $1 charge to help cover the higher fees with this processor.

- On January 29 (one day before), the price will go up to $25 if the event has not sold out. Purchasing your spot as early as possible is recommended.

- RSVP without payment does NOT reserve your spot or lock in the price.

- Online payment deadline is 10:30am on the day of the tour.

- If space is available, payment can be made on-site ($25, cash only).

- Sorry, refunds and exchanges are not available (unless the event is cancelled). However, if you are unable to attend, you can send someone in your place. At check-in, simply have him or her mention the name under which you paid.

- Closest subways are the F at 63rd Street-Lexington Avenue and the 6 at 68th Street-Hunter College.

- If you are late or having trouble finding the group, send "old-fashioned" text only to (917) 680-0656. This is not a smartphone and has no Internet access, so emailing, posting comments on this page, or sending messages through the Meetup site (or app) will NOT work. Also, no voice calls please, as they can be extremely disruptive.

- Please remember to bring photo ID in case it is requested by security at some of the galleries. 

- Feel free to bring your camera.  Taking pictures is allowed.

- The tour will last approximately one and a half hours. Afterward, we will go somewhere nearby for food and socializing if there is interest.

- Gratuities are welcomed. 

- Art novices are welcome, as are people with extensive art backgrounds.

- This event is exclusively for members of my meetup groups and their guests, plus special invitees.  It is not open to the general public. 


See you there!

Milton & Savona
results.name: Special UES Art Gallery Tour: Master Drawings NY ($16 Thru 1/28, Then $25)

Prepay here:

=============================================

The Tenth Annual Master Drawings New York is an event that gives top U.S. and foreign dealers in drawings and watercolors an opportunity to show their best acquisitions to individual and institutional buyers and scholars. The items exhibited at the participating galleries will range from 16th century Old Masters to contemporary works, some newly discovered or not displayed publicly for many years, and will include pencil, ink, chalk, pastel and charcoal drawings, as well as oil on paper sketches and watercolors.

The tour will be led by Savona Bailey-McClain, founder and executive director of the West Harlem Art Fund, an organization that promotes art and culture in parks and other open spaces across NYC, as well as galleries. She has been involved in numerous public art installations and was recently selected to join TINA, a new international network for contemporary art curators based in Italy. In addition, she hosts "State of the Arts NYC", a weekly radio program airing Fridays on WBAI, 99.5 FM.

This is a class in technique although, when you've conquered a song technically, then I will coach musicality and performance. Class size is limited. Fee is $20/per. You may audit the class once (without participating) for $10. Let me know when you sign up if that's your intention.

   People at the front desk are helpful and friendly and the Cafe on the floor has great coffee and cookies, sandwiches, <a>pizza</a>, etc.

   I've been asked to post this:

Dear Members:  This is the first you have heard from me. I am Mr. Harrington's agent/rep. Mr. Harrington teaches privately coaching established actors and singers. For years his private rate has been $120/hr for this service. He started teaching through Meetup earlier this year and has as his goal to bring professional level instruction to the public at a rate that leaves no one behind. This demands tight scheduling of both his time and the room rental with Ripley-Grier Studios.For these reasons, I will be insisting to him that "no shows" be dropped from the group. The policy is this: If you RSVP you better show up. If you cancel you better do this with 24 hours notice. A word to the wise...Michael T. Harvey

results.description:
MARCH 3PM - RALLY at Union Square - South Plaza
4PM - MARCH to Zuccotti Park

On Saturday January 30th, Bernie supporters from every borough and neighborhood will come together in Zuccotti Park where four short years ago Occupy Wall Street lit a fire under the progressive movement that has continued to burn today. Our goal for this rally is to show our New York solidarity to Bernie Sanders and his supporters in Iowa who are heading to the polls for the Caucuses (the first primary in the Democratic presidential nomination process). We plan on bringing supporters throughout NYC and beyond, strengthening our movement for progressive values and cheering Bernie on for a Des Moines win!

Alone, we can only do so much to fight for justice and inequality. But, If we stand together and spark a fire, we will discover that we are more powerful than we ever imagined. We are the people we've been waiting for.

results.description:
Of his choral masterwork, A German Requiem, Johannes Brahms [masked]) wrote: "As for the title, I must admit I should like to leave out the word 'German' and refer instead to 'Humanity'." The scripture texts he chose offer consolation, reassurance, and comfort to the living in a strong affirmation of personal hope, love, courage, and anticipation of joy. They are woven into a rich work full of classical forms and romantic harmonies.


The Park Slope Singers - a member of the Brooklyn community for more than 20 years - proudly introduces our new conductor Dusty Francis for this moving afternoon of music.

Travis Horton and Mikael Darmanie will accompany the chorus, using the composer's own arrangement for piano four hands. The soloists will be Danielle Buonaiuto, soprano, and Paul Max Tipton, bass.

All ticket holders are invited to attend a reception immediately following the concert.

Purchase tickets ($15/pp) in advance here http://parkslopesingers.bpt.me/
results.name: The Park Slope Singers perform "A German Requiem" by Brahms

results.description:
Message from JOHN:

As soon as 4 photographers RSVP in this group and pay, The event will be closed to additional RSVP's. -- Though Maximum attendance is 6, I don;t want to overbook with the other groups attendance.  (Model ratio 1: 2 photographers) Between our Brooklyn group and Manhattan group there are 3 photographers attending (as of Wed, 1/27). If 1 additional photographer attends, I will come to support Monica and be there for technical assistance for all. I'll also bring my speed lights with triggers for members to borrow if they wish. 

Makeup session is from 3-4 ~ Attending photographers are welcome to shoot during the makeup session. As well as shoot the models waiting for their makeup session.  This makeup time is ideal to use as practice shooting for composition, exposure, posing and lens choice.  

Monica is putting together some pretty great events, many members here have never been to a model shoot.  This group is unique in that models are  the host as well. They actively interact with the photographers helping them with ideas that will result in great images. 

A big THANK YOU!  to Monica, she's been really working hard to make this group unique and special!  

On an additional side note, Keep in mine how much these girls are getting paid.  Add it all up and think how it's distributed with 3 models and a makeup artist. for their time at the shoot, the prep and travel time and you will come to realize That you are getting a great bargain!   This is their profession, it's not a hobby.  We all should be thankful that they have been working with WCM and have been willing reduce their rates to make the events affordable to many in the group.  With that being said, I encourage all of you to tip the models as you see fit. 

~John


==========================================================

Don't miss this once in a lifetime opportunity - shoot 3 models. One fair skin toned (Vivian), one tan/olive skin toned (me), one dark rich ebony skin toned (Dorkys). PICTURES OF GUEST MODELS BELOW! It's going to be an epic shoot. Professional makeup artist included

Models:

Vivian:

Monica:

Dorkys:

Location:

Penn station has some amazing tile murals by the entrance to the A subway line.

Price:

$77 + $12 booking fee = $89

The price includes 3 models and a professional mua who will be on-site doing makeup from 3-4 pm. She is AMAZING and her rates are normally $200/hour, but she is discounting her price for me because we are friends. Photoshoot with models will commence after makeup is finished, around 4 pm. 

1 hour makeup, 2 hour photoshoot.

results.description:
Join us for 5.6 mile walk from 96th Street to 18th Street. We will take in a wintry walk along Manhattan's Water-Front and take photos ending west side walk at 5:10 p.m. (exact sunset time for January 30th, 2016)


The Manhattan Waterfront Greenway is a definite way for walking or cycling. We will only be doing 5.3 miles then ending at 96th Street. This is a perfect opportunity to see Manhattan, as I have loved it for years. This is along the park walks and statue filled walks facing our Neighbor State New Jersey.


After our walk we end at the famous City Bakery. The City Bakery located at 3 West 18th Street. This Bakery is known to New York for it's Legendary Hot Chocolate and Pastries. Get on their infamous long line, grab a cup of hot gold with a marsh mellow and talk about the amazing scenery. This is a perfect pay-off to a long cold walk.


Please meet us (Starbucks) and walk to West side Highway's water front where we will walk from Christopher Street to Riverside Park

Please:

1. We Meet at 3:00 p.m. at 96th Street


2. We start in 15 Minutes and walk along the water front


3. Cameras are recommended

4. very important: have fun

5. We want to make it downtown at sunset time 5:10


Please text me when you arrive[masked]

We start at 3:15 pm promptly! (the only cancellation will be due to weather)

1. Please dress warm (we will be walking by the water) during winter


2. Gloves and hats are recommended


3. I suggest layers, enough to keep warm ( not too bulky- we are walking a long distance)


4. Please check the site 24 hours before the event: Single digit, rain or snowy weather will warrant a cancellation of the event


5. I will email everyone 72 hours before the event with my phone number, email and final decision to keep event up or cancel
results.name: West Side Greenway Winter Photography Walk - in time for Sunset
