results.description:
Hello, folks. First of all, I'd like to introduce myself. My name is James Shen. I volunteered to be the new organizer for the Northern NJ Writers meetup. 

Secondly, I want to thank the previous organizer, Candace E. Barnes and assistant organizer, John Adamus for their dedication for the past 13 years. Because of their work, NNJW has a fan base of 407 members. This is amazing for such a small writers' group. It would be a shame for all this to end, if nobody steps up to be the new organizer, so I volunteered.

Next, I want to tell you a little about myself. I am relatively new to meetups. I went to my first meetup last November. I've been searching for the "perfect meetup" ever since. I've tried so many different types of meetups. There are social meetups that range from speed dating, to professional networking. I've tried them all. I still haven't found one that I really love.
I discovered my passion for writing a few months ago, about the same time that I started going to meetups. So I said to myself, why not go to a writers' meetup, since that's your passion in life? Why not surround yourself with others who share the same passion? Therefore, I started searching for a writers meetup. But I have encountered a few problems. 


1. Show up and write
There are some writing meetups that you show up and you write. I think that's pretty dumb because I can write at home, why would I travel to a meetup to write? 

 
2.No regular location
There are other meetups that take place in people's private homes because they don't have a regular location. This gets pretty confusing because I'll be going to a new house at every meetup. 


3.Limit to 2 pages, single spaced
There are some meetups that limit the work that we can bring to 2 pages or 1,000 words. This is pointless because my shortest work is 4-5 pages or 2,000 words. 

 
4.Non-critiquing
Many other writers’ meetups are non-critiquing. So what's the point of going to a writer's meetup if you can't get any feedback? 


5.Monthly meetups
The problem with monthly meetups is that, some of us who bring a long piece of work in smaller parts. By the time you read the second part, you already forgot about the first part, because it's been a month already.
Therefore, my meetup will be a weekly, constructive critiquing meetup at a regular location, with a maximum limit of 2,500 words or 5 pages. We write all our works at home.
In case you haven't notice, I've already made a few changes in our meetup rules. 

 
Rule 1. MEETUP FREQUENCY
Change from MONTHLY to WEEKLY meetup 


Rule 2. VOLUME LIMIT ON WORK
Change from 1-4 pages DOUBLE SPACED work (or 500-1,000 words) to 2-5 pages of SINGLE SPACED work (1,000 to 2,500 words) 


Rule 3. DAY AND TIME OF MEETUP
Change from Monday night at 7pm to Sunday 1 pm. This is because I have a medical condition that make it very difficult for me to drive at night. Since most people work 9 to 5, Mon to Fri, and Saturday is the worst traffic congested day of the week. Sunday is the only option left. 

 
Rule 4. MEETUP LOCATION
Obviously now that the day and time has changed, the location has to be changed also, because the Paramus Barnes & Noble is closed on Sunday. Most stores in Bergen county are closed on Sunday. Therefore, I have to think outside of Bergen county. The next best choice is Wayne, NJ. And I chose the Wayne Burger King.

 
Rule 5. MANDATORY INTRODUCTORY MEETUP FOR ALL MEMBERS, JAN 31ST, Sun, 1 PM at Wayne Burger King.

Rule 6. ATTENDANCE MATTERS 


For those members who do not attend the Intro meetup, will be removed from the group. Those members who miss two or more meetups in a row will also be removed. I apologize, but our space is very limited. We don't need all 407 members. I only need the few loyal members who will attend the meetups regularly and contribute. 

 
Rules 7. RSVP
RSVP end 9 am, Sunday morning.


Rules 8. MULTI-GROUP EVENT
There will be a few new members joining us from my previous writers' group - North Jersey Aspiriting Writers Group (NJAW). (It is a brand new meetup that I created, just a week ago). We have 29 members already as I am writing this letter. There will be a merge happening with these two groups. This is so exciting! I can't wait to meet every one. 


Rule 9. Respect
Be respectful to other writer's work. No discrimination, making fun,or any offensive remarks are tolerated. The offender will be given one warning only and then asked to leave. He or she will be permanently removed from the group. 


Rule 10 Privacy
Respect our privacy. Some of us may write fictions. Other may write our memoirs or autobiographies. These are personal stories that should stay in the group. No gossiping is permitted. Otherwise, the offender will be removed from the group. 


How do I run the writers meetup:


We will meet at the Burger King.  I will wait for people to show up between 12:40-1:10 pm.  The manager will save us a corner.  I will have two signs on the tables that say "North Jersey Aspiring Writers Meetup".  We will take turns read our writings out loud.  I will hand out color pens.  The listeners will critique the writings verbally and in writing.  Be tactful, please.  Be sure to write your name on the top of the first page of the person's work, so we know who made the comments.  By at the end of the meetup, all copies of the work should be returned to the writer.

Complaints: 


I know I will get some complaints from the older members who have to drive an extra 15 miles to get to Wayne. But guess what? I live in Fort Lee, NJ. I have to drive 24 miles to Wayne, NJ. I like to lead by example. I don't want to hear anybody whine and complain for driving less than I do:)

Jan 28, 2016 update - Adding an Icebreaker game

Icebreaking game:

Great news, folks.  A good member has suggested to make my first meetup MORE INTERESTING.  Great idea!  Therefore, I came up with an ICEBREAKING GAME.  It is a great game where we ask ourselves meaningful, thoughtful questions, and get to know each other.  You may even discover things you didn't know about yourself.

Sample questions would be:

1.What are your passions in life? How did you discover them?

2. Describe a negative experience which you turned into a positive one.

3. Would have a billion dollars change you? your friends? your relationship? your passion? your purpose in life?

4. What would be your bucket list?

5. What type of writing are you working on?  What's it about? What made you aspire to be a writer?

group.name: The Northern NJ Writers Meetup Group

results.description:
Hi, everyone.  This is a meetup for any serious, aspiring writers.  It is free. All ages and experiences are welcome. 

**Please bring your work: 1,500-2,000 words, (3 -5 pages, single spaced), staples it, and enough copies for the number of people coming.  

**Check the RSVP right before you come, for the most updated number of people attending.  If there are more than 8 people, then we will break into two groups: FIC & NONFIC.

**Please join my meetup as a member and RSVP the event, and do so ASAP.   This is very important because I need to know how many people will show up. The space is limited, I want to keep my meetup small, around 8 people.  That's two tables.  

And if for any reason, too few people (< 4) RSVPs by 8 pm Saturday night, then I will cancel it.  But if you RSVP and you don't show up, I will remove you from the group.  This is to be fair to everybody who want to come but can't because you are taking up their spot.  

January 31, 2016 will be our introductory meetup.  We can talk about the type of writing we are working on, our writing experience, what made us want to become writers. You can bring your work, we will go over it if time permits. 


My background:

I am relatively new to meetups. I went to my first meetup last November. I've been searching for the "perfect meetup" ever since. I've tried so many different types of meetups. There are social meetups that range from speed dating, to professional networking. I've tried them all. I still haven't found one that I really love. 


I discovered my passion for writing a few months ago, about the same time that I started going to meetups. So I said to myself, why not go to a writers' meetup, since that's your passion in life? Why not surround yourself with others who share the same passion? Therefore, I started searching for a writers meetup. But I have encountered a few problems. 

1. Show up and write 
There are some writing meetups that you show up and you write. I think that's pretty dumb because I can write at home, why would I travel to a meetup to write? 

 
2.No regular location 
There are other meetups that take place in people's private homes because they don't have a regular location. This gets pretty confusing because I'll be going to a new house at every meetup. 


3.Limit to 2 pages, single spaced
There are some meetups that limit the work that we can bring to 2 pages or 1,000 words. This is pointless because my shortest work is 4-5 pages or 2,000 words. 

 
4.Non-critiquing 
Many other writers’ meetups are non-critiquing. So what's the point of going to a writer's meetup if you can't get any feedback? 


5.Monthly meetups 
The problem with monthly meetups is that, some of us who bring a long piece of work in smaller parts. By the time you read the second part, you already forgot about the first part, because it's been a month already. 
Therefore, my meetup will be a weekly, constructive critiquing meetup at a regular location, with a maximum limit of 2,500 words or 5 pages. We write all our works at home. 

Rules of my NJAW (North Jersey Aspiring Writers meetup)

Rule 1 - RSVP and attendance

If you RSVP and you don't show up, you will be removed from the group.  If you think you won't be able to make it, please change your RSVP at least 24 hours before it ends, so that other members can have a chance.

Rule 2 - Respect

Be respectful to other writer's work.  No discrimination, making fun,or any offensive remarks are tolerated.  The offender will be given one warning only and then asked to leave.  Then he or she will be permanently removed from the group.

Rule 3 - Privacy

Respect our privacy. Many of us write fictions.  Others may write our memoirs or autobiographies.  These are personal stories that should stay in the group.  No gossiping is permitted.  Otherwise, the offender will be removed from the group.


How do I run the writers meetup:

We will meet at the Burger King.  I will wait for people to show up between 12:40-1:10 pm.  The manager will save us a corner.  I will have two signs on the tables that say "North Jersey Aspiring Writers Meetup".  We will take turns read our writings out loud.  I will hand out color pens.  The listeners will critique the writings verbally and in writing.  Be tactful, please.  Be sure to write your name on the top of the first page of the person's work, so we know who made the comments.  By at the end of the meetup, all copies of the work should be returned to the writer.

History of NJAW meetup:

This is a brand new meetup created on January 5, 2016.  Maybe there used to be a similar named meetup before that I am not aware of.  But this has nothing to do with the other one.When I first created this meetup, it was called the "Fort Lee Book Writers meetup", since I live in Fort Lee.   Then, I quickly realized that limiting the meetup to only Fort Lee is a huge mistake.  Nowadays, very few people read anymore, even fewer writes.  Writers are a dying breed. It is sad, but true.   So I changed my meetup name to "North Jersey Aspiring Writers meetup" include the entire northern Jersey.  I originally planned to meet on Saturday.  But I soon realized that it was another mistake.  Saturdays are the most traffic congested day of the week.  Sundays are much better.  I apologize for the confusion.

My email: [masked],


My cell phone:[masked]

I look forward to see you there.  

Jan 12, merger announcement update:

Dear NJAW members:

Great news!  I've had a rare opportunity today to take over as the new organizer for a much older writers meetup group called "North NJ Writers group".  It is another small, selective writers group with RSVP of 10 people.  But they have 400 members.  They started in 2003.  They've existed for 13 years.  Their regular meetup time was once a month, on a Monday evening at 7 pm.  Their regular location was the Barnes Noble store at Paramus.  But since I have a medical condition that make it very difficult for me to drive at night, I have to set the meetup during the day.  Most people work 9 to 5 on Mon to Fri.  Saturdays are the most traffic congested day of the week.  Therefore, I chose Sunday.  But here's another thing, Barnes Noble at Paramus is closed on Sundays and so does most other stores in Bergen county.  Therefore, I have to think outside of Bergen county.  Wayne seems to be the next best location.  

I chose the Wayne Burger King.  If everything goes well, our two meetup groups will merge into one.  


JAN 28, 2016 Icebreaker game UPDATE:

Great news, folks.  A good member has suggested to make my first meetup MORE INTERESTING.  Great idea!  Therefore, I came up with an ICEBREAKING GAME.  It is a great game where we ask ourselves meaningful, thoughtful questions, and get to know each other.  You may even discover things you didn't know about yourself.

Sample questions would be:

1.What are your passions in life? How did you discover them?

2. Describe a negative experience which you turned into a positive one.

3. Would have a billion dollars change you? your friends? your relationship? your passion? your purpose in life?

4. What would be your bucket list?

5. What type of writing are you working on?  What's it about? What made you aspire to be a writer?

Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's New York Social Network and their partner Meet Up Groups.  The number of RSVP's listed on your Meet Up reflect only a portion of those actually attending from all the groups participating, you won’t be alone!.  If you have questions regarding this event contact the host directly at [masked] or call[masked]-2256.


You don't have to be a trivia wiz to attend this event!  Our questions are from current events, pop culture and things you should remember from high school! The best part is that if you don't have a team we will set you up with other fun people.  After each round you will also switch seats and be with a totally new team!  It is a fun way to meet others and spend a Sunday afternoon. Here is how it works:


-Arrive at 1pm for mixing and mingling.

-We will randomly set up teams (unless you come with friends)

-Feel free to grab a bite or a beer while you play

-We do 3 rounds of 15 questions each.  After each round we switch everyone around so that you meet new people

Can I come alone?  Yes 98% of those attending come on their own.

Dress code: Sunday casual

Is there food?  Yes they have a full menu.  Pay as you go.

MANDATORY: 1 drink minimum (water does not count)

Transmission Meditation with Meryl Tihanyi Alternate Sundays Beginning March 1st
1:00-3:00pm
Free Do you want to help the world and also build a stronger connection with your own spiritual nature? Transmission Meditation is a simple group meditation that provides both a dynamic service to the world and the opportunity for powerful personal spiritual development. *It is a group meditation based on the Science of Triangles, that makes possible the scientific distribution or transmission of highly potent spiritual energies into the world.
*It is the creation, in conscious co-operation with the Masters of Wisdom, of a vortex or pool of higher energy for the benefit of humanity.
*It is a combination of two yogas: Karma yoga (the yoga of service) and Laya yoga (the yoga of energy or chakras).
*Introduced to the world in 1974 by artist and author Benjamin Creme, there are now hundreds of Transmission Meditation groups active in many countries around the world.
*It is safe, and will enhance and complement any other spiritual practice or service activity in which you may already be engaged. Come to a FREE introduction to Transmission Meditation, followed by a group meditation.

results.description:
Note: Only RSVP if you are planning to show up.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: Monthly membership of $105 (the $99 Initiation Fee is waived if you sign up during the meet up). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is free for first-timers ONLY  (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/
For Beginners, Climbing 101 class is offered 50% Off if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

Due to the weather, this class is now being taught on January 31st.  The times for all classes remain the same for that day. 


January 24, 2016  

Practicing Ethical WitchCraft

o  The Wiccan Rede 

o  The Witch's Creed 

o  The Thirteen Goals of a Witch 

o  The Law of Return ("Threefold Law") 

o  Working With Permission 

o  The Witches Pyramid 

o  What do we believe? 

o  The Principles of Belief 

o  Practical Laws of the Craft 

o  Pentagram / Pentacle – What is its’ meaning? 

o  Magickal Jargon and their meanings in the handout

Imbolc/Imbolg briefing handout

$30 in person/$33 via paypal- PLEASE bring your receipt to class.


WFT Academy of Pagan Studies (WFTAPS) offers the most comprehensive, well-planned and affordable training available anywhere. We have a very interactive community based program. We provide many sources of learning that go into each and every class, which surpasses others when learning about Wicca / WitchCraft in New York City. We offer First through Third Degree training.  We offer First through Third Degree training. Additionally we have many other Witch Crafting Classes & Workshops including: Astrology Series, Organic Herbal Soap Making, Tarot Classes, Besom Making, Candle SpellCrafting and much more. 

What is wonderfully unique about WFT Academy of Pagan Studies is that it allows you to set the pace of your learning experience and provides you with an affordable way to grow within a structured Wiccan learning environment. You will be challenged and we do invite those who welcome this challenge to our Academy. We take your education very seriously, and in turn you should be serious about your education and training in the Path of Wicca / WitchCraft. Before considering enrollment and training at WFT Academy of Pagan Studies keep in mind that it is a life-path commitment.

Within our Academy there is an enormous amount of Community Interaction through the use of meetups, and now our newly formed private FB group just for our students to converse, further enabling you to increase your knowledge and learning as well as providing you the ability to network with other like-minded individuals in a safe and supportive environment.

The Academy is truly a Spiritual Home and we welcome you to make it your own!

We have Degree-specific Study to discuss challenging lessons, facilitate rituals celebrating the Sabbats and Esbats as well as for healing and self-empowerment, all in a friendly and open atmosphere. We also hold Degree dedications marking the stages of your training as you move through the Academy*. We have found that many of our Students find it wonderful to be in a group learning environment that they can consider a Community Home.

We are all very proud of our Academy and what we have accomplished so far. But ever mindful that it is each and every one of the Students that make it what it is. If you are reading this, we are confident that you would make a wonderful addition to our Circle and do hope that after reading you will decide to join us as a Academy Student and member of The NYC Wiccan Family Temple.

We strive to provide a comprehensive selection of training programs and as such offers many other Elective Craft courses and training opportunities for seekers of knowledge and magickal expertise. We encourage you to visit our CURRICULUM PAGE & CRAFT CLASSES PAGE for a complete list of current and future programs.

We welcome you to begin your studies by going to our ADMISSION AND PRICES (where you will find applications) page and submit your enrollment to the Academy today. We look forward to having you join us as a new Student of the WFT Academy of Pagan Studies.

WE ARE ALWAYS IMPROVING UPON WHAT WE OFFER STRIVING AND PROMISING TO ALWAYS KEEP RAISING THE BAR ON WHAT WE OFFER.

WE ARE THE MOST COMPREHENSIVELY TAUGHT WITCHCRAFT ACADEMY WITHIN THE NEW YORK CITY AREA.

IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO FIND OUT FURTHER INFORMATION REGARDING THESE CLASSES, PLEASE GO TO www.wftacademyofpaganstudies.org YOU WILL FIND REGISTRATION INFORMATION, PRICES AND OUR FULL CURRICULLUM. YOU CAN JOIN IN THESE CLASSES AT ANY TIME, AND CATCH UP WITH THE CLASSES YOU MISSED NEXT TIME IT COMES AROUND.

IF YOU HAVE NOT DONE SO, PLEASE DO BRING YOUR APPLICATION FILLED OUT WITH YOU WHEN YOU COME TO CLASS. ALSO, BRING A NOTE BOOK AND PEN OR PENCIL.

There is a one time fee per year of $25.00 registration fee.

If you pay online please bring a receipt of payment as we do not always have time to check paypal the day of the class, or we will expect you pay at the class or gathering.

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON CLASSES, EVENTS ETC. PLEASE VISIT US AT: 
www.wftacademyofpaganstudies.org
www.wiccanfamilytemple.org 
www.thenycpagancouncil.webs.com 
www.romantichandfastings.webs.com 
www.charmedbystarr.com for all your ritual and pagan items.

results.name: Lower East Side Tour. Co-Hosted by Kate from Front Room Gallery!

results.description:
Join your pals from ArtForward and Wired NY (http://www.meetup.com/artforward/) Meetup groups. We'll do a survey of Lower East Side galleries, for the 4th time ever, but the 1st time with a co-host and art insider from Front Room Gallery!

The weather forecast is very promising for this Meetup; bring sunscreen.

There's always something (everything?) inspiring. We'll get to as many galleries as possible. We'll end the tour at a local biergarten type place, for a beverage, and a snack, and brilliant conversation.

Please join in for this almost always super fun event!

If you are lost, you can text me at[masked]-8453.

Hope to see you all soon!
results.name: Lower East Side Tour. Co-Hosted by Kate from Front Room Gallery!

results.description:
As featured by ABC News and Time Out New York, explore what lies beneath the streets of the Big Apple for this warmer, wintertime edition of The Amazing New York Scavenger Hunt. 

This fast-paced three-hour event is a hybrid scavenger hunt-obstacle course where you'll experience the fun & excitement of being part of a team that solves clues & faces mental and (not-so) physical challenges in a race to the finish line. 

Each member of the winning group receives a New York City gift package, and the pictures you'll snap along the way will be priceless.

GET TICKETS HERE ($25 early bird, price will go up to $35) - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/scavenger/dates/Jan-23-2016_at_0130PM

75+ members once again attended our last Scavenger Hunt!  

What to expect:  

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Knowledge about hidden parts of the city

• Mental and (not-so) physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

You can come alone and be placed in a group or you can sign up with friends.  

*Prepay Only Event (No tickets sold at door)

*BUY TICKETS HERE ($25, price goes up as date gets closer) - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/scavenger/dates/Jan-23-2016_at_0130PM 

Prepay only. No tickets sold at door. 

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for to walk. Dress comfortable – Most teams wear running shoes. 

What should I bring? A fun attitude, A Smart Phone if you have (either Android or I-Phone - fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest. Best to download that before you come to the event.

Where do we go? There’s no set course. Find your own way. It’s a ‘choose your own adventure’ race. You will go around the city.

What if it rains? It's underground so the race still goes on. 

Why does your RSVP say +40? This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees. We usually have at least 40 members attend. 

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so PREPAY ASAP here - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/scavenger/dates/Jan-23-2016_at_0130PM

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. 

HAVE EXTRA LAYERS OF CLOTHING. PLEASE DRESS PROPERLY FOR THE WINTER CONDITIONS.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will occasionally comment on some things (the architecture and social history of some of the buildings in the neighborhoods of Park Slope and Victorian Prospect Park South) along the way, but you will have plenty of time to socialize with others. We will, once in a while, stop at points of interest. This walk is about 5 miles and moderate paced. (If you can't keep up with a moderate pace for 5 miles, then this walk is not good for you.)

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John, the Event Host, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo. 

Description: Park Slope has block after block of virtually unaltered architecture from the Civil War to World War One, ranging from brownstones to remarkably picturesque Victorian mansions. In 1890 Census Bureau reported that Park Slope had the highest per capita income in the country and its residents were the leaders of Brooklyn society. 

After Park Slope, we'll go into scenic Prospect Park, passing by an antebellum mansion and skirting past a huge lake. While in Prospect Park, we won't be stopping much except for a restroom break.


Finally, we'll head to the beautiful neighborhood of Prospect Park South, which is just south of Prospect Park. With so many different architectural styles, these Victorian houses in Prospect Park South are whimsically placed next to each other. No two houses are alike in any way!

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer’s Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time/Place:  The meeting time is (after lunch) at 1:45 PM. The meeting place is outside of the entrance to the Central Brooklyn Library at 10 Grand Army Plaza, located at Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway. Before the walk, restrooms are located on the first floor of Central Brooklyn Library, which is open on Sunday from 1:00 PM to 5:00 PM.  

Public Transportation: Take the "Q" subway train to 7th Avenue/Flatbush Avenue and then walk about two blocks along Flatbush Avenue to Grand Army Plaza. Cross over Grand Army Plaza (which has a big traffic circle and can initially be a bit confusing) to the Central Brooklyn Library at 10 Grand Army Plaza (Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway). Or take the No. 2 or 3 subway train to the Grand Army Plaza subway stop and then across Grand Army Plaza (which has a big traffic circle and can initially be a bit confusing) to the Central Brooklyn Library. 

From Manhattan or else, you can also take one of a number of subway lines to the Atlantic Avenue/Pacific Street station (a major transportation hub) and then switch to a Q, 2, or 3 subway train for a short ride. The LIRR train also stops at the Atlantic Avenue/Pacific Street station.

Driving Directions: This is a one-way walk. If you want, you can park your car somewhere around the "Q" subway station at Beverley Road between Marlborough Road and 16th Street. This is near the end of the walk. You can then take the "Q" subway train north (only about 4 subway stops) to the 7th Avenue/Flatbush Avenue subway stop. After getting out of the subway station, walk on Flatbush Avenue for about 2 blocks to Grand Army Plaza (which has a big traffic circle and can initially be a bit confusing) and head across Grand Army Plaza to the Central Brooklyn Library, the meeting place.

Finishing Time/Place:  The walk finishes about 4:50 PM at  the Beverley Road subway station of the "Q" train. This station is on Beverley Road between Marlborough Road and 16th Street.

Rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions or the forecast is for rainy/snowy weather or cold/windy conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Sunday morning. This walk will only happen in good weather conditions. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.

Below was the Charles Feltman mansion at the northwest corner of 8th Avenue and Carroll Street in Park Slope. The mansion was being demolished by wreckers to provide a site for an apartment house. (Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, 1950)

Charles Feltman is generally credited with inventing the hot dog on a bun. According to legend, he came up with the idea of putting a sausage on a roll so he could avoid providing silverware and plates to customers. The restaurant sold millions of hot dogs a year but was better known for its seafood plate including lobster, fish and oysters.

In 1916, Nathan Handwerker, who had worked at the Feltman Restaurant, started his own business a few blocks away on Surf Avenue. Handwerker's Nathan's Famous soon eclipsed his former employer's restaurant and became a Coney Island icon. (Sources Novo  Numismatics)

In the late 19th century, real estate developer Dean Alvord moved from Rochester to Brooklyn and began creating Prospect Park South as a residential park within the limitations of the conventional city block and street. A number of deed restrictions were placed on the lot buyers in order to preserve the unity of the residential park. The sense of a "Country in the City" was what developer Dean Alvord set out to create when he purchased the land from the Flatbush Dutch Reform Dutch in 1892.

(Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, August 2, 1903)

(Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, August 31, 1902)

(Source Architects' and Builders' Magazine)

(Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, April 4, 1906)

(Source The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, July 6, 1907)
results.name: Park Slope to Victorian Prospect Park South, Brooklyn Walk (Jan. 31)

results.description:
Eric Asimov, wine critic for The New York Times, has been running a monthly wine "school" column for the newspaper's readers. He selects a region, does a little write-up, and identifies three wines to try. After drinking the wines, people go to the newspaper's on-line comments section to have a conversation about what they've learned and liked. I've had fun doing this for several months, but thought it might be even better with some of you. Let's try to meet monthly, where reasonable, to drink and talk!

The point of this group is to teach and learn from each other.  All levels are welcome, though we do want participation in tasting and discussing the wines from all.  We keep the group small so we can focus on the wines!  Good behavior is a must, as we will be meeting in a private residence.


What to bring: Each participant will be expected to read Asimov's monthly wine write-up and bring one bottle of wine recommended in the article. He generally identifies three specific bottles, and also lists alternates if the three are not available. I find smooth.com and wine-searcher.com helpful in figuring out which wine shops might have the bottle you are looking for.  But they're not foolproof: call the shop to confirm is recommended.  I generally have had good luck at Astor Wines, Flatiron Wines, 67 Wines, Union Square Wines and Sherry-Lehmann Wines. Please make every effort to find the specific bottles listed by Asimov. Be sure to post a comment with which wine you will be bringing so that we can have a variety of bottles. Some bottle duplication will be inevitable, but we do want some variety. 

Because wine needs food, each participant should also bring something tasty to eat and share. 

Cost:  The cost of the Asimov Wine School meetups will vary depending on the cost of that month's wine.  Generally it's been somewhere between $15-$70 for the bottle you bring plus the cost of whatever snack you select to share.

January's details:  We'll be drinking from Marsannay Burgundy this month. Read Eric Asimov's January Wine School article here:
results.name: Marsannay Burgundy tasting

group.name: Wine Tasting "School" of New York and more!

results.description:
Happy New Year!  For our first meetup of 2016, our number one book from the poll is:

From Amazon:  "An unmissable milestone for fans of Sir Terry Pratchett: the first SF novel in over three decades in which the visionary inventor of Discworld has created a new universe of tantalizing possibilities—a series of parallel “Earths” with doorways leading to adventure, intrigue, excitement, and an escape into the furthest reaches of the imagination."

From book jacket:  "The possibilities are endless. (Just be careful what you wish for. . . .)

1916: The Western Front. Private Percy Blakeney wakes up. He is lying on fresh spring grass. He can hear birdsong and the wind in the leaves. Where have the mud, blood, and blasted landscape of no-man's-land gone? For that matter, where has Percy gone?

2015: Madison, Wisconsin. Police officer Monica Jansson is exploring the burned-out home of a reclusive—some say mad, others allege dangerous—scientist who seems to have vanished. Sifting through the wreckage, Jansson finds a curious gadget: a box containing some rudimentary wiring, a three-way switch, and . . . a potato. It is the prototype of an invention that will change the way humankind views the world forever."


LOCATION
We will be meeting at the Citigroup Atrium.

There is an entrance at 53rd and Lexington Avenue off of the 53rd and Lex subway stop. You have to go down the steps; the subway station will be on your right and the Atrium will be straight in front of you. The doors are labelled.   

There is a Barnes and Noble (with a Starbucks inside) located on the next level up at 54th and 3rd. If you enter through the B&N, you will need to go through B&N (up a few steps from the entrance), past the NOOK display to the glass doors and down the escalator to the Atrium.

There is free wi-fi in the Citigroup Atrium. There are also free public restrooms. Please let me know if you have any questions about the location.

It's probably more fun if you read/finish the book.  But if you don’t, you are still welcome to come. But there will be spoilers!

WHERE TO BUY
The book is available in hardcover and digital, including Kindle</a> at Amazon<a href="http://www.amazon.com/Inferno-Book-1-Larry-Niven-ebook/dp/B001F784EG"> and a Nook at Barnes & Noble.


IMPORTANT RSVP POLICY
If you RSVP and find you cannot make it, please change your RSVP so that we are not waiting for you. Please change it no less than two hours before the scheduled meeting time. If you RSVP and do not show, you will have to pay $10 when you attend your next event. This is to prevent those on the waiting list from missing out on an event.   

The RSVP policy is the same as for the general meetup. Please see the entire policy here:  http://www.meetup.com/NYSciFi-Fantasy/pages/Membership_Policy/

Each meditation includes an introduction, followed by a time in which to meditate in whatever way is easy and natural to you.

results.description:
Come out and play! Mild weather is forecast! Lets' get movin'!

We'll walk the pier loop with NYC views and peeks at the new Tappan Zee Bridge  construction in the distance.  From there we will walk by some of the towns'  historical homes and bridge and then do a little walking in Tallman State Park(conditions permitting). If we're lucky we may see some migratory ducks and birds so bring your binoculars and cameras!

This will be about a 2 hour walk on mostly cleared paved, level paths with a possible moderate incline on crushed gravel with possibly some packed down remaining snow.

Good weather resistant walking or hiking shoes recommended along with dressing in layers as it can get windy out on the pier.  Water is mandatory.

Optional dinner at the new Austin's Piermont Restaurant serving New American with an Irish flair and something for everyone!  Reasonable prices, good food and separate checks!  What more could you ask for!

 THERE IS PLENTY OF PARKING ON THE SQUARE, BY THE LIBRARY, AND IN THE BIG PARKING LOTS BEHIND  CONFETTIS RESTAURANT , ACROSS FROM THE LIBRARY.  INCLEMENT WEATHER CANCELS, SO ALWAYS CHECK THE DAY OF AN EVENT, FOR ANY CHANGES.

results.description:
Please Register HERE

Join the Photo Brigade for a special panel event at Adorama in NYC on the Business of Editorial Photography featuring some of the best sports photographers on the planet: David Bergman, Rob Tringali, Al Tielemans, and via Skype, Robert Seale! They’ll talk about their collective 100+ years of experience working for the top publications of our times. What defines their success isn't just their incredible skill at capturing amazing moments, but their business savvy. That means having an understanding for the administrative end of their jobs as photographers, invoicing, promoting themselves, reviewing contracts, and most importantly when to say "no”. This is an event you won’t want to miss! Join us in Adorama’s Event Space or watch us LIVE at PhotoBrigade.com/live! David Bergman is best known for his tour photography, portraiture, and sports imagery. A former Miami Herald staff photographer, he is now Bon Jovi’s tour photographer and has worked with celebrity clients including Drew Carey, Avril Lavigne, Gloria Estefan, and Joss Stone. He has 13 Sports Illustrated covers to his credit including the 2010 Super Bowl. His panoramic Gigapan image of President Obama’s inauguration was viewed online over 30 million times, and he has made similar images at the World Series, Super Bowl, and Final Four. Bergman has produced still and video projects for companies including FremantleMedia, Embassy Row, EMI, and SONY Music and has been published in Rolling Stone, Time, Newsweek, People, Entertainment Weekly, Blender, USA Today, and The New York Times. DavidBergman.net

Robert Seale is a Houston-based corporate and advertising photographer who shares his behind the scenes stories, lighting diagrams, favorite photo gear, and tips and tricks. Known for his innovative lighting, action packed sports portraits, thoughtful problem solving, and colorful annual report photography, Robert Seale shoots portraits of people for magazines, Fortune 500 corporations, design firms, and advertising agencies all over the world. RobertSeale.com

Al Tielemans, based out of the Philadelphia area, shoots editorial, corporate, advertising assignments and stock imagery. A long time Sports Illustrated contributor, Tielemans has over SI 100 covers to his credit. He has covered 13 Olympic games, 24 Super Bowls, 21 World Series, and countless feature stories with the great athletes of our time.AlTielemans.com

Rob Tringali is a New York based sports photographer who has been shooting athletes and sporting events for editorial and commercial clients like ESPN The Magazine and Sports Illustrated for over 20 years.RobTringali.com
results.name: Photo Brigade Panel w/ David Bergman, Robert Seale, Al Tielemans & Rob Tringali

As most of you know, this WILL BE OUR LAST GAME AT THIS LOCALE ... under several incarnations (Quinn's, Harley's Smokeshack, Irish Rogue), this building has been our home for most of the existence of this Peña: the place where we officially came alive, where we saw a Pasillo Clásico, and of course, where we celebrated LA DÉCIMA!!!

But all good things, as always, must come to an end ... so, on Sunday, after we beat Espanyol (we better!), let's all stick around, have a few bites and more than a few drinks, and make it a memorable last ride at our future old home.

Some details for right after the game:

* FOOD PAID FOR BY PEÑA: wings, potato skins, chicken fingers, beef sliders and more...

* Drinks will be pay-as-you-go, good deals: $4 domestic beers, $5 Mahou, $6 house mixed drinks.

Hope to see y'all there!

And yes, we will be announcing our next candidate home in the next few days, so stay tuned for that ... hey, HALA PEÑA-MADRIDISTA-NYC!

results.description:
Only 8% of people making New Year's Resolutions actually achieve them. A big reason is that they don't acknowledge the underlying reason WHY they set them in the first place - the goal isn't an extension of their life's vision.


Join us as we welcome the author of "Your Spirit at Work", Christine Clifton to Short Stories for a unique event. Learn how to bring more of YOU, through what you DO, so your vision comes TRUE. In this interactive presentation, Christine will guide you through the foundational principles that will help you more strongly ground your desires into true motivation.

NOTE:  While there is no fee for this gathering, we WILL strongly encourage a bookstore purchase in order to thank our host.


************************************

Christine Clifton is a social introvert, an author and a wordsmith, a service professional, a creative dancer, a former corporate manager – and a practical spiritualist. She believes that everybody matters and deserves to be heard: the world is a lesser place without your unique voice in it!


Often, we’re caught up in service to others – our bosses, families, and community – and we put ourselves to the bottom of the list. We don’t know what we want – so we don’t ask for what we need – and our lives don’t look like we thought they would. 


Christine guides Mindful Entrepreneurs and Professionals Say what they need to Say, so they can Get where they want to Go, and Earn what they’re Worth. “You don’t have to shout to Stand Out.”

Find out more at www.MindfulBusinessMatters.com.

NOTE:  While there is no fee for this gathering, we WILL strongly encourage a bookstore purchase in order to thank our host.
results.name: "Your Spirit at Work" presentation in Madison, NJ

results.description:
INTERMEDIATE ACOUSTIC GUITAR WORKSHOP

I would now like to announce a monthly meetup for intermediate players which will happen on the 4th Sunday of the month. There are five Sundays in this month, and this meetup will happen on the last Sunday.


In this 90-MINUTE SESSION you will discover what is available out of participating in the group while you advance your knowledge and guitar playing skills: You will expand your ability to read notes, learn to play a new song and work on playing with other musicians.  Want to learn the notes in the upper positions on the neck?  You will have new materials to practice over the next month to help you retain what you've learned and hone those new chops for the next jam session you encounter.


YOU KNOW YOU'RE INTERMEDIATE IF:
You are intermediate if you know how to play chords well enough that you can play songs with correct rhythm, you are able to read standard music notation to some degree, and perhaps you can read tablature. Maybe you've taken formal lessons from a teacher before.

BRING YOUR ACOUSTIC GUITAR TO PARTICIPATE.  No need to bring a music stand--we'll have music stands and chairs for everyone.


COST:  $15.00 per person and must be paid at the time of RSVP.  NO WALK-INS.  You must be registered to attend.


MINIMUM # OF ATTENDEES: 4--We must have at least 4 people RSVP's "yes" at 48 hours before the event; otherwise the event will be cancelled.

results.description:
No preparation needed for this meeting! Just bring up to 1,500 words of writing—a flash piece or an excerpt from a longer piece you are working on or the outline of an idea that you need help with. People are encouraged to bring work generated through Writing Room exercises.

The format works like this:

Each writer gets a total of up to 30 minutes, which begins when they read their piece aloud or give a pitch of their idea in five minutes or less. We will be able to do 4 or 5 pieces/ideas per meeting. Names will be drawn at random. (Anyone whose work is not chosen will get priority at the next meeting.) You don’t need to bring work to attend and no advance preparation is required.

Please feel free to bring drinks or snacks. Arielle has power strips to plug in and space to write at both a table and on couches and chairs. Also, there are two cats, in case anyone has allergies.

See you there!
results.name: On-the-Spot Workshop Critique Group

results.description:
[Cross-posted from NYC Stoics]


Nero and Seneca (Eduardo Barrón, 1904)


Stoicism is a philosophy for living. But how well can it actually be lived with wealth, power, and danger afoot?

Seneca, the Roman philosopher, senator, writer, and tutor and adviser to the emperor Nero, lived the answer to this question, and that will be what we explore first in 2016.

We will start off a year of studying Seneca by reading James Romm's recent book on Seneca's life (and death by suicide) at the court of Nero entitled Dying Every Day. The book can be purchased electronically or physically through most booksellers.

To prepare for this meetup, please read from the Introduction through Chapter 4: Matricide and post at least one question, passage, or concept from the book that you would like to discuss at the meetup in the conversation thread below.
results.name: Dying Every Day I

We will start off our "year of Seneca" by reading James Romm's recent book on Seneca's life (and death by suicide) at the court of Nero entitled Dying Every Day. The book can be purchased electronically or physically through most booksellers.


To prepare for this meetup, please read from the Introduction through Chapter 4: Matricide. Also, post at least one question, passage, or concept from the book that you would like to discuss at the meetup in the conversation thread below.

[Note: if you would like to participate in this meetup but purchasing the book presents a financial burden to you, please contact Greg privately to arrange getting a copy]

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 3:30-5:30pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.

results.description:
Photographer & Model Photoshoot Society Presents:

"Model Spotlight: Glamour & Implied Shoot w/Marlene #2 - Jan. 31st"

(Rescheduled Snow Date)

(Update: This is the shoot for waitlisters that will take place after the first initial Meetup. Same three themes and same amount of shooting time as first shoot, just shorter overall timeframe for an even smaller group.)

With the success of our last Model Spotlight, we decided to setup another Spotlight shoot this month with returning beauty Marlene. She was such a big hit last time and we're happy to have her back at the studio for this glamour and pre-valentine shoot.

About Model Spotlight shoots:

With this type of shoot there will be one model. (Limited smaller group than our bigger shoots) It could be a traveling model, one of our member favorites or a model with a unique concept. These shoots are designed to be more intricate as far as lighting scheme, concepts and free form. (The freedom to adjust lighting, sets, add props and make the look your own with plenty of time to do so.) We will have a basic starting point for the look but you are encouraged to experiment. (I will be on hand to help where needed.)

About the Shoot:

First we will shoot Marlene in swimwear in one of our backdrops for a pinup style. Second look will be lingerie using our LED lighting which proved very popular at our last shoot. Third, will be an implied look with a "bed of roses", pre-valentine look.

RSVP:

NEW: Please take a moment to read the new Deposit info below in the Policy and Disclaimers section. From here on in, we have setup a deposit system to hold a spot for a shoot. This will ensure that we have the minimum amount of RSVP to actually hold the Meetup. So, please only sign up when you are sure of your attendance and ready to make the deposit. (This also lets anyone on a waitlist able to join the shoot if you are not sure of your attendance yet.) Your spot is not held till the deposit is received and I'll send you a confirmation message or confirm your spot on the Meetup page. (No, deposit is needed if you are on the waitlist but check back to see if your waitlist status has been updated to "Yes".)

Total Cost: $70

Deposit: $20 (Paypal)

(Don't mark the checkbox as that adds the surcharge automatically. If we have to return a deposit for any reason, it will be less than originally deposited.)

Balance due at time of shoot: $50, Cash preferred, Credit Cards/Paypal ok with $5 added for surcharge.

Non-Commercial Release PDF will be emailed to you at the email address given on the sign in sheet.

Model: 

Marlene (Marly Mar) : Instagram or Facebook

(Photos provided by model for promotional purposes only. All rights their respective owners.)

Policy and Disclaimers:

One-on-One: The model will be available for one half hour one on one shoot after the first two hours in the Meetup. If you want to pre-book time before the shoot, send me a message.

Shared One-on-Ones: We are also implementing a system that has been working for the past few Meetups. It's the sharing of a half hour one on one with a fellow photographer. It can be shared together for the whole half hour or 15 minutes each photographer. 

____________________________________________________________________

About the Studio:

The studios is a beautiful 3,000 sq. ft., climate controlled,  fully functional studio. (Professional in-house lights, props, various seamless backdrops, actual commercial photography sets, kitchen, waiting room, meeting/presentation room, the works!) It's conveniently located to major highways and a 20-30 minute public transportation ride to and from NY.

About The Meetup Format:

We will keep the group small although we have the space to accommodate a big group. This keeps things from feeling rushed and overwhelming. Each photographer will have a set amount of time per look. This will allow you to  shoot as you would in an actual client shoot and not have to worry about the number of shots you are taking. (This proved to be ideal in our previous shoots as far as being able to get "the shot" and enough time to do so. Think of it as a mini one-on-one time with the model.) During the shoot we may opt to give a theme a direction to shoot for. As it would be for an actual client. (Ex: If the setup calls for a "cover shot" then it will give you a direction to aim for and to consider what equipment to use or what mood to capture.) No worries, bring what lens or lenses you have, you'll learn to use what you have for best results. We strive to bring forth real world conditions and parameters so there is a methodology to a setup or theme.

Check-in Procedure and Disclaimers:

Check-in - When you arrive, there will be a quick check-in. This will mostly be so you can read and adhere to the studio/group shoot guidelines and make payment for the shoot before we start. This will also let us send you the release forms in PDF format if we don't have physical copies available.

Releases - We will have one non-commercial release signed by the model through the studio only. (No additional releases will be signed.) If you need a commercial release signed, you can make arrangements with the model directly. Additional compensation for this is between the model and photographer.

Right to Refuse - We have the right to refuse a member's RSVP to the Meetup. It's a small community and models keep detailed info on photographers also. If we feel there is justifiable reason to refuse a RSVP, we will exercise that right.

Signups - Please signup when you know you will attend. If the signup passes the point to book another model and then we get no shows it's not fair to your fellow photographers who would be on a waiting list. It also puts the organizers in a tough spot, financially after booking an additional model to compensate for a bigger group. In case of no show, we will have to remove you from the group. When emergencies come up, followup with an email and we can make exceptions on a case by case basis. 

Deposit - We have implemented a deposit system to insure that the minimum RSVP is met to hold the shoot. (Which varies from shoot to shoot.) This will ensure that the financials are or will be in place for the models beforehand. This deposit will be non-refundable, so make sure you sign up and pay the deposit when you are sure you will be able to attend. Signing up to the Meetup page does not ensure your spot until the deposit is made at the Paypal link provided on each event page. You will receive a confirmation message or a confirmation comment on the Meetup page you are signing up for. Two days before the shoot, if the minimum RSVP has not been met then we will opt to cancel the shoot and refund any deposits already sent. This will give the model some time to book another gig if possible. But as usual, always check the Meetup page up to the date of the shoot for any updates.

Model Cancellation - If a model cancels/no show or a last minute model change occurs, you will have the option to cancel beforehand or not attend the Meetup on the day of, if it happens upon arrival to the Meetup. (Any refunds will be given or credit toward a future Meetup as per your request.)

Waitlist - When you are on a wait list, please be mindful as this is also considered a RSVP of availability. So, if we add another model or someone cancels, your wait list status may upgrade to a "Yes" automatically. Please be on the lookout for updates on the Meetup page as Meetup sometimes takes longer to notify of a status change.

Updates - Updates will be made on this page up to the date of the Meetup or the night before. Emails will also be sent but Meetup emails are not always reliable to be sent to a receiver right away. (I've heard of emails arriving 3 hours later if at all.)

Postponements - Weather considerations will be made the night before a shoot or on the day of and the Meetup page will be updated as well as emails sent if a postponement occurs due to inclement weather or some other emergency. Lack of minimum RSVP to hold the event will also cause postponement of the shoot. The night before we would make the call wether to postpone so be on the look out for our email and Meetup page updates.

Any questions please email me at [masked]

results.description:
Chinese New Year's here and we simply have to eat our way into it, the Chinese style. :) So let's do food for our next workshop!

"Food and sex are basic human desires." That should go without saying - but wait, it was Confucius who said it! (《礼记·礼运篇》: “饮食男女，⼈之⼤欲存焉。") 


Chinese are not known for enjoying talks on sex (other than Confucius? :)), but are definitely famous for delighting in food in every way possible. Even the offerings for our ancestors on the days of remembrance can be eye-popping.
We'll go over some must-know food vocabulary, some new year stuff, as well as useful expressions for our favorite pastime - dining and wining.

Please prepare: The name of your favorite Chinese dish.

Kat has a system of learning spoken Mandarin that aims at better retention by more implicit learning. Come ready to talk! :D

*Chinese Workshop lessons are conducted in English and Mandarin. Each workshop is a stand-alone lesson/practice, and not intended for native speakers of Chinese. Thanks for your understanding. :) 这个 workshop 旨在学习中⽂，不适合母语为中⽂的朋友，请见谅！:)

*There's a $10 event fee to go toward the Meetup Organizer subscription charge as well as the lesson. Thanks!

*You can opt in our shared dinner (and cost) or order your own.

*You can check out our past Workshops outside the U.S. at: http://www.meetup.com/Chinese-Workshop-Europe/

And happy Year of the Monkey!

Please join us for January's discussion of "Binti" by Nnedi Okorafor. Please come with an open mind, a spirit of fellowship, and a point of view.

I'm looking forward to seeing you there!

Christina 

***Book Synopsis***

Her name is Binti, and she is the first of the Himba people ever to be offered a place at Oomza University, the finest institution of higher learning in the galaxy. But to accept the offer will mean giving up her place in her family to travel between the stars among strangers who do not share her ways or respect her customs.

Knowledge comes at a cost, one that Binti is willing to pay, but her journey will not be easy. The world she seeks to enter has long warred with the Meduse, an alien race that has become the stuff of nightmares. Oomza University has wronged the Meduse, and Binti's stellar travel will bring her within their deadly reach.

If Binti hopes to survive the legacy of a war not of her making, she will need both the the gifts of her people and the wisdom enshrined within the University, itself ― but first she has to make it there, alive.

***Where to Find the Book***

results.description:
Hi, Christina here, your quirk leader! 


Some of you may know my story, and if not... I used to be a professional rockstar. I'm the least rockstar, rockstar, ever, haha. But, I did tour the U.S. as a singer in a rock band, playing over 200 shows in 2009. I've also had the joy of offering my vocals for film, tv, theater, and lots of other awesome gigs!

I used to say I would be crazy or dead had it not been for music. There is something inexplicably nourishing + healing when you can tap into the flow of music.

The single most important thing singing taught me was how to free my voice and express myself. Yes, melodically, but mostly I mean soulfully. 

I apply this same freedom of expression in everything. Conversations, other forms of art, business, cooking, cleaning, or even as I'm walking on the street. 

Every single thing we do in life is an opportunity to express. 

Yet so often, we, you and I, all choose a seemingly safer route, putting up layers of protection, and filtering the raw, wild emotions. 

For a long time, the stage, music, my voice felt like the only safe place. Off-stage certain things were seen as too much vs. on-stage they were admired. 

The #1 reason I first decided to create The Quirk Thing: A Stage for the Unconventional was to offer this same safe place to express.

I'd also love to offer some extra support off-stage in the form of a Quirkshop! An experiential workshop for discovering and exploring your QuirkPowers!

On special occasions, I've been teaching singing. Especially those who consider themselves, "non-singers."

I believe anyone can sing. If you can talk, you are already using melody, rhythm, and pitch change. For instance, right now, out loud say... "Hello?" and then say "Hello!" Sounded different, yes? Those are the basics of singing, but with elongated vowels ;-)

However, I'm not just going to "teach you to sing." This is more than simply getting better at singing karaoke. 

This is about connecting with the voice that's already within you, the deeper expressions longing to be heard.

Expressing your soul through song in order to experience everyday life

• with more ease of being, 

• feeling comfortable in your own skin, 

• and trusting in your self. 

If there's an expression wanting to come out, and could use a little bit of love and guidance... I'd love for you to join me in this Quirkshop: Free Your Voice & Express Your Soul!

For 90 mins, we will explore the voice in some really simple vocalizations and some of the expressions you're wanting to share more for yourself. No pressure to jump in the spotlight, yet you won't be drowned out in a crowd. A group experience honoring each individual.

p.s. You do NOT need to be a singer or have aspirations for being a professional singer, this is about using your voice and expressions in music for your enjoyment and in living everyday life more fully alive.

p.p.s. If this terrifies you, worry not fellow quirkster! I promise I always infuse experiences with fun + sensitive respect + extra loving. So, if you're desiring a place to explore outside of your comfort zone, you'll be in a super supportive atmosphere. <3

results.name: Quirkshop: Free Your Voice & Express Your Soul

• PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHANGE YOUR RSVP IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE;

Characters

Weller Martin

Fonsia Dorsey

two elderly residents at a nursing home for senior citizens, strike up an acquaintance. Neither seems to have any other friends, and they start to enjoy each other's company. Weller offers to teach Fonsia how to play gin rummy, and they begin playing a series of games that Fonsia always wins. Weller's inability to win a single hand becomes increasingly frustrating to him, while Fonsia becomes increasingly confident.

While playing their games of gin, they engage in lengthy conversations about their families and their lives in the outside world. Gradually, each conversation becomes a battle, much like the ongoing gin games, as each player tries to expose the other's weaknesses, to belittle the other's life, and to humiliate the other thoroughly.

results.description:
As previously announced, the Movie Appreciation Workshop is finished and I'm shifting gears to teaching the Directors Access Workshop.

Did you ever want to learn how to direct actors for film?   


Come to our FREE open house to learn more about the "Directors Access Workshop" as Jeremy takes you through his six-point directing method.  See live scene demonstrations with actors.  And get your questions answered about the upcoming 8 week "Director Access Workshops."

More about the DIRECTORS ACCESS WORKSHOP:

During the "Directors ACCESS Workshop", Jeremy Wechter will teach you how to evoke powerful performances to tell the story you envision. While learning Jeremy’s six point ACCESS method, you will have the opportunity to practice the ACCESS method by directing actors in short movie scene rehearsals during each class. 


Jeremy will coach you through these rehearsals to help guide you to your vision. You will have the opportunity to observe your fellow directors working with the same scene and actors during each class in order to witness how much a director’s input can radically change any scene for better or worse. And by the final class, you will select a movie scene of your choice and direct that scene rehearsal in class to implement what you have learned.

"Directors ACCESS Workshop" is a fun and safe place to explore your craft of directing the actor while expanding your director’s tool box and skill set. When a scene is not working, directors often make a misdiagnosis of where the problem emanates. This workshop is a great opportunity to discover how to correct that common mistake by learning all six points of Jeremy’s ACCESS method. During the workshop you’ll learn to diagnose a performance problem accurately, so the correct method of adjustment can be implemented. This workshop is open to directors of all experience levels.

Check out our website:

http://directorsaccess.wix.com/workshop
results.name: FREE Directors Access Workshop

results.description:
I always find it interesting to explore some of the lesser-known regions within the big wine-producing countries.  Among Spanish wines, Rioja, Ribera del Duero, and Priorat are all great but by now familiar.  What about the wines of Navarra and Aragón—what are they like?  Let’s find out.

Navarra and Aragón are two long-ago kingdoms that nowadays most people outside Spain would be hard pressed to find on a map.  Navarra is now best known for its capital city Pamplona and the famous running of the bulls.  Aragón, which as a kingdom once extended as far as Naples and Sicily, is now a sparsely populated region centered on the historic city of Zaragoza. 

Navarra is in northeastern Spain, sandwiched between Rioja to the south and the Pyrenees to the north.  As in much of Spain, winemaking here goes back many centuries, achieving particular renown in the 14th century, when Navarra wine became popular among pilgrims along the Camino de Santiago.  Another peak period was in the second half of the 19th century, when vines in nearby France were devastated by phylloxera and Navarra vineyards remained unaffected (for a while . . . the pest reached Spain around the turn of the century).  

Navarra has a temperate, Mediterranean climate, moderated by the nearby Pyrenees, Ebro River, and the Bay of Biscay.  Modern Navarra winemaking has been influenced by two nearby regions—Rioja to the south and Bordeaux in nearby France.  Tempranillo is the most grown grape, with Bordeaux varietals, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, gaining ground.  A considerable amount of Garnacha is also grown, made into full-bodied reds as well as the wine that is probably most closely associated with Navarra—the signature local rosé.  This is made by the saignée method, in which the must is allowed up to 12 hours of skin contact, resulting in a distinctive electric, glow-in-the-dark pink hue.  If 10-year-old girls could qualify as sommeliers, they would be ardent proponents of Navarra rosé—no other wine is a prettier, more vibrant pink. 

We will start the dinner with one of those pink wines, then move on to three Navarra reds—one made from Graciano (that other Rioja grape), one from Garnacha (an uncommonly elegant example), and one Bordeaux blend, made mostly from Cabernet Sauvignon with a bit of Merlot and Cab Franc mixed in. 

Aragón is a larger, more diverse region, also south of the Pyrenees, that is divided into several subregions.  Garnacha dominates in all of them, often producing big, highly extracted wines in this hot, continental climate.  We’ll be trying Garnachas from three of the subregions:

Campo de Borja: This is an arid region situated between the Ebro and La Huecha rivers.  (The Borgias of Renaissance Italy had their roots in this area, thus the name.)  This is a region of old-vine, low-yielding Garnacha that can vary in character depending on the elevation of the vineyard (the high-altitude Alto Moncayo Garnachas have earned 100-point Wine Advocate scores).  We’ll be trying the unfortunately named Fagus (the name might account for the fact that only two US retailers listed on Winesearcher carry it).  Old vines, very low yields, producing a powerful but elegant wine. 

Calatayud:  Like Campo de Borja, this is a hot, arid region featuring low-yielding Garnacha.  Old vines are particularly prized here, and wines from vines over 50 years old are entitled to the designation Calatayud Superior. Since Calatayud achieved DO status in 1990, modern, independent winemakers have been attracted to the region, but there’s a consistently highly rated Calatayud Garnacha made by a cooperative—the widely distributed, value-priced Las Rocas.  We’ll be trying the premium bottling by Bodegas Ateca, an old-vines Garnacha that spent 18 months in French oak. 

Somontano:  Aragón’s most dynamic and varied wine region.  The name means “under the mountain,” appropriate for this region that sits in the Pyrenees foothills.  Unlike Campo de Borja or Calatayud, Somontano looks like a flourishing wine region, with ample rainfall and rolling green hills.  After the Somontano DO was established in 1984, international varieties became the appellation’s calling card, but competing with better established Cabernets and Syrahs in the marketplace proved difficult.  The modern Viñas del Vero winery sets the standard for the region, especially with its single-estate Secastilla Garnacha, which we will be trying in the 2010 vintage. 

We’ll be returning to Piccola Trattoria in Dobbs Ferry for an early Sunday dinner.  They did a great job of hosting our Argentina event. 

http://piccolany.com/

2014 Viña Zorzal Garnacha Rosado (Navarra)  $10

Not reviewed.  From Chambers Street Wines:  Viña Zorzal offers some seriously delicious wines from old vines for very little money. This one honors the traditional wine of the Navarra region—rosado of Garnacha—and is made from the Sanz family's low-yielding, head-trained, organically farmed, old-vine Garnacha. Fragrant red currant, raspberry, and pink peppercorn aromas lead to distinctive crushed cranberry and strawberry fruit, with zesty pink grapefruit, tropical, and herbal undertones on the finish. Zorzal offers impressive concentration, freshness, and complexity at an unbelievable price.

2013 Viña Zorzal Graciano (Navarra)  $11

Jancis Robinson 16.5/20 – An easier year to pick Graciano at good ripeness, apparently, and it does not need as long in bottle as some earlier vintages. Matures for 5 months in used French oak.  Deeper crimson. Fabulously aromatic even though it is restrained—the quality of the aroma more than the intensity. And just a touch of oak spice. Firm and a little chewy on the palate, the oak very well-integrated, just adding a little to the structure and depth. Has all the fragrance of Graciano but with refined structure too.

2009 Pago de San Gabriel Zubiola (Navarra)  $21

Tanzer 91 – (90% Cabernet Sauvignon, 5% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Franc, raised in new French oak.) Opaque ruby.  Intense raspberry preserve and candied flowers on the nose and palate.  Silky and seamless in texture, with red fruit and great lift and definition for a hot vintage.  Sweet berry and floral pastille notes linger on a long, spicy, focused finish.

2010 Domaines Lupier El Terroir (Navarra)  $32

Wine Advocate 92 – The 2010 El Terroir is a barrel selection of the argilo-calcareous Garnacha vineyards, which is hitting it on all cylinders, with a floral, red and black berry aromas, as well as balsamic notes with just hints of spices and smoke. The palate is medium-bodied with ultra-fine tannins and a silky texture that makes it very pleasant and easy to drink. Drinking beautifully today, it should last quite a bit. Drink 2016-2021.

2012 Bodegas Aragonesas Fagus de Coto de Hayas (Campo de Borja, Aragon)  $22

Wine Advocate 91 – The 2012 Fagus de Coto de Hayas is a selection of Garnacha from 40- to 50-year-old vineyards, which aged in contact with the lees in new French oak barrels for ten months. It's very aromatic and perfumed, with strong notes of flowers and ripe small red and blueberries, hints of incense and vanilla, very showy and attractive, perhaps a little over the top. The palate is medium-bodied, with glossy, sophisticated tannins and a fine texture. This is a sleek, showy wine.

2010 Bodegas Ateca Atteca Armas (Calatayud, Aragon)  $43

Tanzer 92 – (All Garnacha; aged in French oak for 18 months.) Opaque ruby.  Sexy, oak-spiced dark berries and incense on the nose.  Broad and palate-coating, offering sweet black and blue fruit flavors that pick up spiciness and florality with air.  Juicy and precise on the finish, showing impressive tenacity and supple, harmonious tannins.

2010 Viñas del Vero Secastilla (Somontano, Aragon)  $45

Jancis Robinson 15.5/20 – Garnacha. Ten months in French oak barrels. Signature cuvée from Viñas del Vero.  Smoky, ripe and very toasty displaying chocolate notes and a minty lift. The palate is really intense and ample, with a palatable oak sensation and bitter touch. Slightly drying now. It is very modern in style.
results.name: Navarra and Aragón

Join us this Sunday evening for another great night of Cinema Italiano!!

We will show La Migliore Offerta (The Best Offer), 2013. Our Italian director, Academy Award Winner Giuseppe Tornatore, decided to shoot this entire movie in English. To respect the actors authenticity, we will show the movie in it's original language, English.  

        ---> Trailer and Tickets on our Website Here <---

The film tells a story of love and deceit, set in Europe in the world of high-end art auctions and antiques. The film stars Geoffrey Rush and Donald Sutherland, and the music score is composed by Ennio Morricone. 

Popcorn and Soda will be Complimentary during the movie, and right after the screening we will go around the corner to Emporio Restaurant, to enjoy a complimentary beer offered by our sponsor Peroni.

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

In honor of the 88th Oscars this year, we are seeing The Revenant. The Alejandro González Iñárritu film has been nominated for 12 awards. Staring Leonardo DiCaprio, the film is based on the old legend frontiersman Hugh Glass who survives being abandoned and surviving in the wilderness .

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LoebZZ8K5N0


The film has allowed DiCaprio to win the Golden Globes and as predicted, he is on his way to the Oscars.

The cinematography is said to be amazing and well done and the story-line well written.


This year as a result of our Membership, we are now able to create a group purchase. Members will have first dibs (priority) on group tickets. This will allow us to sit together and get tickets at a EWNYC group rate. Member price is $8.00  Anyone can purchase their ticket on the day of the event at $14.50

Because the membership dues was used to reserve tickets, members reserve the right to first dibs. New Policy

Members: $8.00

Buying tickets on your own: $14.50(you can purchase your ticket at the location) (Regular) at a later time separate screening room

I will be at the location at 6:30 p.m. - The movie starts promptly at 7:00 p.m.

Movie Rules:

• I will be at the location at 6:30 p.m.

• With a list of members attending

• The movie starts at 7:00 p.m

• We will by-pass waiting line. pick ticket up at window

• We will collectively go in together.

• We will select seats - the earlier we get there, the better our seats will be

• Members can make their way to concession stands and purchase food.

• If we sit together, we can hold seats while others get food and etc.

Please call me with any questions

Olisa
